editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nicole Sheriko

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: Comedies and tragedies written by Francis Beaumont and Iohn Fletcher ...
titleStmt.author: Beaumont, Francis, 1584-1616.
Fletcher, John, 1579-1625.
Shirley, James, 1596-1666.
Lowin, John, 1576-1659.
Taylor, Joseph, 1586?-1653?

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Incubo the bailiff, Diego the host.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Signior don Diego, and mine host, save thee.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I thank you Mr. baily.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: O the block.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Why, how should I have answered?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Not with that
Negligent rudeness: but I kiss your hands
Signior don incubo de Hambre, and then
My titles; master baily of Castil-blanco:
Thou ne'er wilt have the elegancy of an host;
I sorrow for thee, as my friend and gossip:
No smoke, nor steam out-breathing from the kitchen?
There's little life i'th hearth then.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Ay, there, there,
That is his friendship, harkening for the spit,
And sorrow that he cannot smell the pot boil.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Strange
An inn should be so cursed, and not the sign
Blasted, nor withered; very strange, three days now,
And not an egg eat in it, or an onion.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I think they ha' strewed the highways with cal-traps, ay,
No horse dares pass 'em; I did never know
A week of so sad doings, since I first
Stood to my signpost.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Gossip, I have found
The root of all; kneel, pray, it is thyself
Art cause thereof: each person is the founder
Of his own fortune, good, or bad; but mend it,
Call for thy cloak, and rapier.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Do, call,
And put 'em on in haste: alter thy fortune,
By appearing worthy of her: dost thou think
Her good face ere will know a man in cverpo?
In single body, thus? in hose, and doublet?
The horse boys garb? base blank, and half blank cverpo?
Did I, or Mr. Dean of civil our neighbour
Ere reach our dignities in cverpo, thinkst thou,
In squirting hose, and doublet? Signior, no,
There went more to't: there were cloaks, gowns, cassocks
And other paramentos; call, I say,
His cloak, and rapier here. Enter hostess.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.l: What means your worship?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Bring forth thy husband's sword: so hang it on,
And now his cloak, here, cast it up; I mean
Gossip, to change your luck, and bring you guests.

sp.speaker: Hostess
sp.l: Why? is there charm in this?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Expect; now walk,
But not the pace of one that runs on errands;
For want of gravity in an host, is odious:
You may remember gossip, if you please,
(Your wife being then th' infanta of the Gipsies,
And yourself governing a great man's mules then)
Me a poor squire at Madrid attending
A master of ceremonies; but a man, believe it,
That knew his place to the gold weight, and such
Have I heard him oft say, ought every host
Within the Catholic Kings dominions
Be in his own house.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A master of ceremonies:
At least vice-master, and to do naught in cverpo,
That was his maxim; I will tell thee of him:
He would not speak with an ambassadors cook,
See a cold bake-meat from a foreign part
In cverpo: had a dog but stayed without,
Or beast of quality, as an English cow,
But to present itself, he would put on
His Savoy chain about his neck, the ruff
And cuffs of holland, than the Naples hat
With the Rome hatband, and the Florentine agate,
The Milan sword, the cloak of Genua, set
With Flemish buttons, all his given pieces
To entertain 'em in, and complimentKnock within.
With a tame coney, as with the prince that sent it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: List, who is there?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A guest and 't be thy will.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Look spouse, cry luck, and we be encountered: ha?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Luck then, and good, for 'tis a fine brave guest,
With a brave horse.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Why now, believe of cverpoEnter Theodosia.
As you shall see occasion: go, and meet him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Look to my horse, I pray you, well.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He shall sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: O how beneath his rank and call was that now?
Your horse shall be entreated as becomes
A horse of fashion, and his inches.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Look to the cavalier: what ails he? stay
If it concern his horse, let it not trouble him,
He shall have all respect the place can yield him
Either of barley, or fresh straw.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Good sir
Look up.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: He sinks, somewhat to cast upon him,
He'll go away in cverpo else.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: What, wife!
O your hot waters quickly, and some cold
To cast in his sweet face.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Alas, fair flower?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Does anybody entertain his horse?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes, Lazaro has him.

div.stage: Enter hostess with a glass of water.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Go you see him in person.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Sir, taste a little of this, of mine own water,
I did distil't myself; sweet lily look upon me,
You are but newly blown, my pretty tulip.
Faint not upon your stalk, 'tis firm and fresh
Stand up, so, bolt upright, you are yet in growing.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray you let me have a chamber.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That you shall sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And where I may be private, I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: For that introth sir, we ha' no choice: our house
Is but a vent of need, that now and then
Receives a guest, between the greater towns
As they come late; only one room,

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: She means sir, it is none
Of those wild, scattered heaps, called inns, where scarce
The host is heard, though he wind his horn t'his people,
Here is a competent pile, wherein the man,
Wife, servants, all do live within the whistle

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Only one room.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A pretty modest quadrangle
She will describe to you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Wherein stands two beds sir
We have, and where, if any guest do come,
He must of force be lodged, that is the truth sir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: But if I pay you for both your beds, methinks
That should alike content you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: That it shall sir.
If I be paid, I am prayed.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why, there's a ducat
Will that make your content?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O the sweet face on you:
A ducat? yes, and there were three beds sir,
And twice so many rooms, which is one more,
You should be private in 'em all, in all sir,
No one should have a piece of a bed with you
Not master Dean of civil himself, I swear
Though he came naked hither, as once he did
When he'd like t'have been ta'en a-bed with the Moor
And guelt by her master: you shall be as private,
As if you lay in's own great house, that's haunted,
Where nobody comes, they say:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I thank you hostess.
Pray you will you show me in.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yes marry will I sir,
And pray that not a flea, or a chink vex you

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: You forget supper: gossip: move for supper

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Tis strange what love to a beast may do, his horse
Threw him into this fit.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: You shall excuse me
It was his being in cuerpo, merely caused it.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Do you think so sir?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Most unlucky cuerpo,
Naught else, he looks as he would eat partridge,
This guest; ha' you 'em ready in the house?
And a fine piece of kid now? and fresh garlic,
With a Sardina, and Zant oil? how now?
Has he bespoke? what will he have a brace,
Or but one partridge, or a short legged hen,
Daintily carbonadoed?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Alas the dead
May be as ready for a supper as he.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: He has no mind to eat, more than his shadow:

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Say you.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: How does your worship

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I put on
My left shoe first today, now I perceive it,
And skipped a bead in saying 'em o'er; else
I could not be thus crossed: he cannot be
Above seventeen; one of his years, and have
No better a stomach?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And in such good clothes too

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Nay, those do often make the stomach worse, wife,
That is no reason.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I could at his years gossips
(As temperate as you see me now) have eaten
My brace of ducks, with my half goose, my coney,
And drink my whole twelve marvedis in wine
As easy as I now get down three olives.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: And with your temperance-favour, yet I think
Your worship would put to't at six and thirty
For a good wager; and the meal in too.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I do not know what mine old mouth can do,
I ha' not proved it lately

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: That's the grief sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: But is he without hope then gone to bed?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I fear so sir, has locked the door close to him
Sure he is very ill.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: That is with fasting,
You should ha' told him gossip, what you had had,
Given him the inventory of your kitchen,
It is the picklock in an inn, and often
Opens a close barred stomach: what may he be trob?
Has he so good a horse?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: O a brave jennet,
As ere your worship saw.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And he eats

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Strongly,

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: A mighty solecism, heaven give me patience,
What creatures has he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And so well clothed,
And so well mounted?

sp.speaker: Di g.
sp.l: That's all my wonder sir,
Who he should be; he is attired and horsed
For the constable's son of Spain.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: My wonders more
He should want appetite: well a good night
To both my gossips: I will for this time
Put off the thought of supping; in the morning
Remember him of breakfast pray you,

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'T shall sir,

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: A hungry time sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: We that live like mice
On others meat, must watch when we can get itExit Incubo.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Yes, but I would not tell him: our fair guest
Says, though he eat no supper, he will pay for one.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Good news: we'll eat it spouse, 't his health,
'Twas politicly done t'admit no sharers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look to the mules there, where's mine host?

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Here sir.
Another fairy.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Bless me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: From what sweet hostess?
Are you afraid of your guests?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: From angels sir,
I think there's none but such come here tonight ,
My house had never so good luck afore
For brave fine guests; and yet the ill luck on't is
I cannot bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not lodge you sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not, hostess?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: No in troth sir, I do tell you
Because you may provide in time: my beds
Are both ta'en up by a young cavalier
That will, and must be private.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He has paid sir
For all our chambers.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Which is one: and beds
Which I already ha' told you are two: but sir,
So sweet a creature, I am very sorry
I cannot lodge you by him; you look so like him
You're both the loveliest pieces.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What train has he?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: None but himself.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And will no less than both deeds
Serve him?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Has given me a ducat for 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O.
You give me reason hostess: is he handsome,
And young do you say?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O sir, the delicat'st flesh
And finest clothes withal, and such a horse,
With such a saddle.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She's in love with all.
The horse, and him, and saddle, and clothes: good woman,
Thou justifiest thy sex; lovest all that's brave:
Sure though I lie o'th ground, I'll stay here now
And have a sight of him: you'll give me houseroom,
Fire, and fresh meat for money: gentle hostess
And make me a palate?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir she shall do reason:
I understood you had another guest: gossips
Pray you let his mule be looked too: have good straw,
And store of bran: and gossip do you hear,
Let him not stay for supper: what good fowl ha' you?
This gentleman would eat a pheasant.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Las sir;
We ha' no such.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I kiss your hands fair sir.
What ha' you then? speak what you have? I'm one sir
Here for the Catholic King, an officer
To inquire what guests come to these places; you sir
Appear a person of quality, and 'tis fit
You be accommodated: why speak you not,
What ha' you woman? are you afraid to vent
That which you have?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is a most strange man;
'T appoint my meat.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The half of a cold hen sir,
And a boiled quarter of kid, is all i'th house.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Why all's but cold; let him see it fourth,
Cover, and give the eye some satisfaction,
A traveller's stomach must see bread and salt,
His belly is nearer to him, than his kindred:
Cold hen is a pretty meat sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What you please;
I am resolved to obey.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: So is your kid,
With pepper, garlic, and the juice of an orange,
She shall with salads help it, and clean linen;
Dispatch: what news at court sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith new tires
Most of the ladies have: the men old suits,
Only the King's fool has a new coat
To serve you.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I did guess you came from thence sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I do know I did not.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I mistook sir.
What hear you of the archdukes?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Troth your question.

div.stage: Enter hostess and servants with table.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Of the French business, what?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As much.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: No more?
They say the French: oh that's well: come I'll help you:
Have you no giblets now? or a broiled rasher
Or some such present dish t'assist?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not any sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: The more your fault; you never should be without
Such aids: what cottage would ha' lacked a pheasant
At such a time as this? well, bring your hen,
And kid forth quickly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That should be my prayer
To scape his inquisition.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir, the French,
They say are divided about their match with us,
What think you of it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As of naught to me sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Nay it's as little to me too: but I love
To ask after these things, to know the affections
Of states, and princes, now and then for bettering.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Of your own ignorance.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Yes sir:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Many do so.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I cannot live without it: what do you hear
Of our Indian fleet; they say they are well returned.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I had no venture with 'em sir; had you?

div.stage: Enter hostess and servants with meat.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Why do you ask sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Cause it might concern you,
It does not me.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: O here's your meat come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thanks,
I welcome it at any price.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Some stools here,
And bid mine host bring wine, I'll try your kid,
If he be sweet: he looks well: yes, he is good;
I'll carve you sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You use me too too princely:
Taste, and carve too.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I love to do these offices.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I think you do: for whose sake?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: For themselves sir,
The very doing of them is reward.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Had little faith would not believe you sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.p: Gossip some wine. Enter Diego with wine.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Here 'tis: and right saint Martin.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Measure me out a glass.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I love the humanity
Used in this place:

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir, I salute you here.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I kiss your hands sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Good wine; it will beget an appetite:
Fill him; and sit down, gossip, entertain
Your noble guest here, as becomes your title.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Please you to like this wine sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I dislike
Nothing mine host, but that I may not see
Your concealed guest: here's to you.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: In good faith sir,
I wish you as well as him: would you might see him.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And wherefore may he not:

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: 'Has locked himself sir
Up, and has hired both the beds of my wife
At extraordinary rate.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll give as much
If that will do't, for one, as he for both;
What say you mine host, the door once open
I'll fling myself upon the next bed to him
And there's an end of me till morning; noise
I will make none.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I wish your worship well — but

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: His honour is engaged: and my she gossip
Hath passed her promise, hath she not?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes truly:

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: That toucheth to the credit of the house:
Well, I will eat a little, and think: how say you sir
Unto this brawn o'th hen?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ha' more mind
To get this bed sir.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Say you so: why then
Give't me again, and drink to me: mine host
Fill him his wine: thou'rt dull, and dost not praise it,
I eat but to teach you the way sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sir:
Find but the way to lodge me in this chamber
I'll give mine host two ducats for his bed,
And you sir two reals: here's to you

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Excuse me,
I am not mercenary: gossip pledge him for me,
I'll think a little more; but e'en one bit
And then talk on: you cannot interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: This piece of wine sir cost me

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Stay: I have found:
This little morsel: and then: here's excellent garlic:
Have you not a bunch of grapes now: or some bacon
To give the mouth a relish?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Wife, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: It is no matter. Sir, give mine host your ducats.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Do you receive 'em: I will save
The honesty of your house: and yours too gossip,
And I will lodge the gentleman: show the chamber.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Good sir do you hear.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Show me the chamber.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Pray you sir,
Do not disturb my guests.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Disturb? I hope
The Catholic King sir, may command a lodging
Without disturbing in his vassals house,
For any minister of his, employed
In business of the state. Where is the door?
Open the door, who are you there? within?
In the King's name. Theodosia within.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Your key sir,
And your door open: I have here command
To lodge a gentleman, from the justice, sent
Upon the King's affairs.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Kings and necessities
Must be obeyed: 'The key is under the door.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: How now sir, are you fitted? you secured?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Your two reals are grown a piece of eight.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Excuse me sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twill buy a hen; and wine
Sir, for tomorrow. Exit. Phil.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I do kiss your hands sir
Well this will bear my charge yet to the galleys
Where I am owing a ducat: whither this night
By the moon's leave I'll march: for in the morning
Early they put from port s. Mary's. Ex. all but Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: LazaroEnter Lazaro.
How do the horses?

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Would you would go and see sir,
A — of all jades, what a clap has given me:
As sure as you live master he knew perfectly
I cozened him on's oats: he looked upon me
And then he sneered, as who should say take heed sirrah:
And when he saw our half peck, which you know
Was but an old court dish: lord how he stamped:
I thought 't had been for joy, when suddenly
He cuts me a back caper with his heels
And takes me just o'th' crupper: down came I
And all my ounce of oats: then he neighed out
As though he had had a mare by'th tail.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Faith Lazaro
We are to blame to use the poor dumb serviters
So cruelly.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Yonder's this other gentleman's horse
Keeping our lady eve: the devil a bit
Has got since he came in yet: there he stands
And looks, and looks, but 'tis your pleasure sir
He shall look lean enough: has hay before him
But 'tis as big as hemp, and will as soon choke him,
Unless he eat it buttered: he had four shoes
And good ones when he came: 'tis a strange wonder
With standing still he should cast three.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: O Lazaro
The devils in this trade: truth never knew it
And to the devil we shall travel Lazaro
Unless we mend our manners: once every week
I meet with such a knock to mollify me
Sometimes a dozen to awake my conscience
Yet still I sleep securely.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Certain master
We must use better dealing.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'faith for mine own part
Not to give ill example to our issues,
I could be well content to steal but two girths,
And now and then a saddle cloth: change a bridle
Only for exercise.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: If we could stay there
There were some hope on's master: but the devil is
We are drunk so early we mistake whole saddles
Sometimes a horse; and than it seems to us too
Every poor jade has his whole peck, and tumbles
Up to his ears in clean straw, and every bottle
Shows at the least a dozen; when the truth is sir
There's no such matter, not a smell of provender,
Not so much straw, as would tie up a horse tail,
Nor any thing ith' rack, but two old cobwebs
And so much rotten hay as had been a hen's nest.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Well, these mistakings must be mended Lazaro,
These apparitions, that abuse our senses,
And make us ever apt to sweep the manger
But put in nothing; these fancies must be forgotten
And we must pray it may be revealed to us
Whose horse we ought in conscience to cozen,
And how, and when: a parson's horse may suffer
A little greasing in his teeth, 'tis wholesome;
And keeps him in a sober shuffle: and his saddle
May want a stirrup, and it may be sworn
His learning lay on one side, and so broke it:
Has ever oats in's cloak-bag to prevent us
And therefore 'tis a meritorious office
To tithe him soundly.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: And a grazier may
For those are pinching puckfoysts and suspicious:
Suffer a mist before his eyes sometimes too,
And think he sees his horse eat half a bushel:
When the truth is, rubbing his gums with salt,
Till all the skin come off: he shall but mumble
Like an old woman, that were chewing brawn,
And drop 'em out again.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: That may do well too,
And no doubt 'tis but venial: but good Lazaro
Have you a care of understanding horses,
Horses with angry heels, gentlemen's horses,
Horses that know the world: let them have meat
Till their teeth ache; and rubbing till their ribs
Shine like a wench's forehead; they are devils

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: And look into our dealings: as sure as we live
These courtiers horses are a kind of Welsh prophets,
Nothing can be hid from 'em: for mine own part
The next I cozen of that kind, shall be foundered,
And of all four too: I'll no more such compliments
Upon my crupper.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Steal but a little longer
Till I am lamed too, and we'll repent together,
It will not be above two days.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: By that time
I shall be well again, and all forgotten sir.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Why then I'll stay for thee. Exit.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Theodosia and Phillipo on several beds.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O, — ho -? o — ho?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O — o? heart — heart — heart — heart?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: When wilt thou break? — break, break, break?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?
I would the voice were strong, or I nearer,

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Shame, shame, eternal shame? what have I done?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Done?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And to no end: what a wild journey
Have I more wildly undertaken?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Journey?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How without counsel? care? reason? or fear?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Whither will this fit carry?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O my folly:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is no common sickness.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How have I left
All I should love, or keep? O heaven.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How do you gentle sir?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas my fortune

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: It seems your sorrow oppresses: please your goodness
Let me bear half sir: a divided burden
Is so made lighter.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That sigh betrays
The fullness of your grief:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ay, if that grief
Had not bereft me of my understanding,
I should have well remembered where I was,
And in what company; and clapped a lock
Upon this tongue for talking.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Worthy sir
Let it not add to your grief, that I have heard
A sigh, or groan come from you: that is all sir:

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Good sir no more: you have heard too much I fear,
Would I had taken poppy when I spoke it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It seems you have an ill belief of me
And would have feared much more, had you spoke ought
I could interpret. But believe it sir
Had I had means to look into your breast,
And ta'en you sleeping here, that so securely
I might have read, all that your woe would hide
I would not have betrayed you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir that speech
Is very noble, and almost would tempt
My need to trust you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At your own election,
I dare not make my faith so much suspected
As to protest again: nor am I curious
To know more than is fit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir I will trust you
But you shall promise sir to keep your bed,
And whatsoe'er you hear, not to importune
More I beseech you from me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir I will not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Then I am prone to utter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My faith for it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: If I were wise, I yet should hold my peace
You will be noble.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You shall make me so
If you'll but think me such.

sp.speaker: Theo
sp.l: I do: then know
You are deceived with whom you have talk so long.
I am a most unfortunate lost woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Do not stir sir: I have here a sword.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not I sweet lady: of what blood, or name.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You'll keep your faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll perish else.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Believe then
Of birth too noble for me, so descended —
I am ashamed, no less than I am affrighted.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fear not: by all good things, I will not wrong you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am the daughter of a noble gentleman
Born in this part of Spain: my father's name sir:
But why should I abuse that reverence
When a child's duty has forsaken me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: All may be mended: in fit time too: speak it

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alphonso, sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alphonso? what's your own name?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Any base thing you can invent.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Deal truly.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: They call me Theodosia

sp.speaker: Phi●.
sp.l: Ha? and love
Is that that hath changed you thus?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ye have observed me
Too nearly sir, 'tis that indeed: 'tis love sir.
And love of him (O heavens) why should men deal thus?
Why should they use their arts to cozen us?
That have no cunning, but our fears about us?
And ever that too late to; no dissembling
Or double way but doting: too much loving?
Why should they find new oaths, to make more wretches?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What may his name be?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir a name that promises
Methinks no such ill usage: Marc-antonio
A noble neighbour's son: now I must desire ye
To stay a while: else my weak eyes must answer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will: — are ye yet ready? what is his quality?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: His best a thief sir: that he would be known by;
Is, heir to Leonardo, a rich gentleman:
Next, of a handsome body, had heaven made him
A mind fit to it. To this man, my fortune,
(My more than purblind fortune) grave my faith ▪
Drawn to it by as many shows of service
And signs of truth, as ever false tongue uttered:
Heaven pardon all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis well said: forward lady.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Contracted sir, and by exchange of rings
Our souls delivered: nothing left unfinished
But the last work, enjoying me, and ceremony.
For that I must confess was the first wise doubt
I ever made: yet after all this love sir,
All this profession of his faith; when daily
And hourly I expected the blessed priest
He left me like a dream, as all this story
Had never been, nor thought of, why I know not;
Yet I have called my conscience to confession,
And every syllable that might offend
I have had in shrift: yet neither love's law signior,
Nor ty of maiden's duty, but desiring
Have I transgressed in: left his father too,
Nor whither he is gone, or why departed
Can any tongue resolve me: all my hope
(Which keeps me yet alive, and would persuade me
I may be once more happy, and thus shapes me
A shame to all my modest sex) is this sir,
I have a brother and his old companion,
Student in Sallimanca, there my last hope
If he be yet alive, and can be loving
Is left me to recover him: for which travel
In this suit left at home of that dear brothers
Thus as you find me, without fear, or wisdom,
I have wandered from my father, fled my friends,
And now am only child of hope and danger:
You are now silent sir: this tedious story
(That ever keeps me waking) makes you heavy:
'Tis fit it should do so: for that, and I
Can be but troubles.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, I sleep not lady:
I would I could: o heaven is this my comfort.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What ail you gentle sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why do you groan so?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I must, I must; o misery.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: But now sir
You were my comfort: if any thing afflict ye
Am not I fit to bear a part on't? and by your own rule.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No; if you could heal, as you have wounded me,
But 'tis not in your power.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I fear intemperance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay do not seek to shun me: I must see you:
By heaven I must: hoa, there mine host: a candle:
Strive not, I will not stir ye.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Noble sir
This is a breach of promise.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tender lady
It shall be none but necessary: hoa, there,
Some light, some light for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Will ye betray me?
Are ye a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good woman:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir. Enter Diego with a light.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If I be prejudicial to you, curse me.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Ye are early stirring sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give me your candle
And so good morrow for a while.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Good morrow sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: My brother don Philippo: nay sir, kill me
I ask no mercy sir, for none dare know me,
I can deserve none: as ye look upon me
Behold in infinite these foul dishonours
My noble father, than yourself: last all
That bear the name of kindred, suffer in me:
I have forgotten whose child I am, whose sister:
Do you forget the pity tied to that:
Let not compassion sway you: you will be then
As foul as I, and bear the same brand with me,
A favourer of my fault: ye have a sword sir,
And such a cause to kill me in.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Rise sister:
I wear no sword for women: nor no anger
While your fair chastity is yet untouched.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By those bright stars, it is sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For my sister
I do believe ye: and so near blood has made us
With the dear love I ever bore your virtues
That I will be a brother to your griefs too:
Be comforted, 'tis no dishonour sister
To love, nor to love him you do: he is a gentleman
Of as sweet hopes, as years, as many promises,
As there be growing truths, and great ones.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O sir!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Do not despair.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Can ye forgive?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes sister,
Though this be no small error, a far greater.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And think me still your sister?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My dear sister.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And will you counsel me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To your own peace too:
Ye shall love still.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How good ye are?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My business,
And duty to my father, which now drew me
From Salimanca, I will lay aside
And only be your agent to persuade ye
To leave both love, and him, and well retire ye.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O gentle brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I perceive 'tis folly:
Delays in love, more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Noble brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fear not, I'll run your own way: and to help you,
Love having racked your passions beyond counsel:
I'll hazard mine own fame: whither shall we venture?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas, I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, 'tis bright morning
Let's walk out, and consider: you'll keep this habit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I would sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then it shall be: what must I call ye?
Come, do not blush: pray speak, I may spoil all else.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray call me Theodoro. Enter Diego.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Are ye ready?
The day draws on a pace: once more good morrow.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good morrow gentle host: now I must thank ye:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who dost thou think this is?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Were you a wench sir
I think you would know before me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mine own brother.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.l: By'th mass your noses are a kin: should I then
Have been so barbarous to have parted brothers?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You knew it then.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.l: I knew 'twas necessary
You should be both together: instinct signior
Is a great matter in an host.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am satisfied. Enter Pedro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is not mine host up yet?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'll see.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sister, withdraw yourself.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Signior Philippo

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Noble don Pedro, where have you been this way?

sp.speaker: Pedr
sp.l: I came from port saint Mary's, whence the galleys
Put this last tide, and bound for Barcelona,
I brought Mark-antony upon his way.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Mark-antony?

sp.speaker: Pedr
sp.l: Who is turned soldier
And entertained in the new regiment,
For Naples.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I assure you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And put they in at Barcelona?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: So
One of the masters told me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way go you sir?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Home:

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And I for civil: pray you sir, say not
That you saw me, if you shall meet the question,
I have some little business

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Were it less sir.
It shall not become me, to lose the caution:
Shall we breakfast together?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'll come to you sir:
Sister you hear this: I believe your fortune
Begins to be propitious to you: we will hire
Mules of mine host here: if we can himself
To be our guide, and straight to Barcelona,
This was as happy news, as unexpected
Stay you, till I rid him away.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I will. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis open sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: That's all one
Knock when I bid you.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Will not your worship enter.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Will not you learn more manners sir, and do that
Your master bids ye; knock ye knave, or I'll knock
Such a round peal about your pate; I enter
Under his roof, or come to say god save ye
To him, the son of whose base dealings has undone me.
Knock louder, louder yet: I'll starve, and rot first,
This open air is every man's.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: Within.come in sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, no sir, I am none of these come in sirs
None of those visitants: bid your wise master
Come out, I have to talk unto him: go sir

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: Your worship may be welcome.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sir, I will not,
I come not to be welcome: good my three ducats
My pickled sprat a day, and no oil to't,
And once a year a cotton coat, leave prating
And tell your master, I am here.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.l: I will sir.
This is a strange old man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I welcome to him!
I'll be first welcome to a Pesthouse: Sirhah
Let's have your valour now cased up, and quiet
When an occasion calls, 'tis wisdom in ye,
A serving man's discretion: if you do draw
sp.stage: Enter Leonardo, and don Zanchio (Carried by two servants in a chair.)
sp.l: Draw but according to your entertainment;
Five nobles worth of fury.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Signior Alphonso.
I hope no discontent from my will given,
Has made ye shun my house: I ever loved ye.
An credit me amongst my fears 'tis greatest
To minister offences.

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: O good signior
I know ye for Italian breed, fair tongued,
Spare your apologies, I care not for 'em,
As little for your love sir; I can live
Without your knowledge; eat mine own, and sleep
Without dependences, or hopes upon ye.
I come to ask my daughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am not gentle sir, nor gentle will be
Till I have justice, my poor child restored
Your caper-cutting boy has run away with
Young signior-smooth-face, he that takes up wenches
With smiles, and sweet behaviours, songs, and sonnets,
Your high fed jennet, that no hedge can hold
They say you bred him for a stallion.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Fie signior, there be times, and terms of honour
To argue these things in, descidements able
To speak ye noble gentlemen, ways punctual
And to the life of credit, ye are too rugged.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I am too tame sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye hear but reason?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, I will hear no reason: I come not hither
To be popped off with reason; reason then.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Why signior, in all things there must be method
Ye choke the child of honour else, discretion,
Do you conceive an injury?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: What then sir?

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Then follow it in fair terms, let your sword bite
When time calls, not your tongue.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I know sir
Both when and what to do without directions,
And where, and how, I come not to be tutored,
My cause is no man's but mine own: you signior
Will ye restore my daughter?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who detains her?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No more of these sleight shifts

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye urge me signior
With strange unjustice: because my son has erred

sp.speaker: Zanch
sp.l: Mark him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Out of the heat of youth: dost follow
I must be father of his crimes.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I say still
Leave off your rhetoric, and restore my daughter.
And suddenly: bring in your rebel too,
Mountdragon, he that mounts without commission
That I may see him punished, and severely,
Or by that holy heaven, I'll fire your house,
And there's my way of honour.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Pray give me leave
Was not man made the noblest creature

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Should not his mind then answer to his making,
And to his mind his actions, if this ought to be,
Why do we run a blind way from our worths,
And cancel our discretions, doing those things
To cure offences, are the most offences?
We have rules of justice in us; to those rules
Let us apply our angers: you can consider
The want in others of these terminations,
And how unfurnished they appear.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hang others,
And where the wrongs are open, hang respects,
I come not to consider.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Noble sir,
Let us argue coolly, and consider like men.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Like men!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are too sudden still.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Like men sir?

sp.speaker: Zanch
sp.l: It is fair language, and allied to honour.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Why, what strange beast would your grave reverence
Make me appear? like men!

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Taste but that point sir,
And ye recover all.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I tell thy wisdom
I am as much a man, and as good a man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All this is granted sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: As wise a man.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Ye are not tainted that way.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And a man
Dares make thee no man; or at best, a base man.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Fie, fie, here wants much carriage.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hang much carriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Give me good language sirrah signior.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Give me my daughter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am as gentle as yourself, as free born.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Observe his way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: As much respect owed to me.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: This hangs together nobly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And for civil
A great deal more it seems: go look your daughter.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: There ye went well off signior.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That rough tongue
You understand at first: you never think sir
Out of your mightiness, of my loss: here I stand
A patient anvil, to your burning angers
Made subject to your dangers; yet my loss equal:
Who shall bring home my son?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: A whipping beadle.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, is your daughter whorish?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha, thou dar'st not,
By heaven I know thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I dare more sir
If you dare be uncivil.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Laugh too, pigeon.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: A fitter time for fame's sake: two weak nurses
Would laugh at this; are there no more days coming,
No ground but this to argue on? no swords left
Nor friends to carry this, but your own furies?
Alas! it shows too weakly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Let it show,
I come not here for shows: laugh at me sirrah?
I'll give ye cause to laugh.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are as like sir
As any man in Spain.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: By heaven I will,
I will brave Leonardo.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Brave Alphonso,
I will expect it then.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Hold ye there both,
These terms are noble.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ye shall hear shortly from me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now discreetly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Assure yourself ye shall: do ye see this sword sir?
He has not cast his teeth yet.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Rarely carried.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: He bites deep: most times mortal: signior
I'll hound him at the fair and home.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Still nobly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And at all those that dare maintain ye.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How you shall please sir, so it be fair, though certain,
I had rather give you reason.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Fairly urged too.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: This is no age for reason, prick your reason
Upon your sword's point.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: Admirably followed.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And there I'll hear it: so till I please, live sir.Exit

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And so farewell, you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Zanch.
sp.l: The end crowns all things
Signior, some little business past, this cause I'll argue
And be a peace between ye, if't so please ye,
And by the square of honour to the utmost:
I feel the old man's mastered by much passion,
And too high racked, which makes him overshoot all.
His valour should direct at, and hurt those
That stand but by as blenchers: this he must know too,
As necessary to his judgement, doting women
Are neither safe nor wise adventures: conceive me,
If once their wills have wandered; nor is't then
A time to use our rages: for why should I
Bite at the stone, when he that throws it wrongs me?
Do not we know that women are most wooers
Though closest in their carriage? Do not all men know,
Scarce all the compass of the globe can hold 'em
If their affections be afoot? shall I then covet
The follies of a she-fool, that by nature
Must seek her like, by reason be a woman,
Sink a tall ship because the sales defy me?
No, I disdain that folly; he that ventures
Whilst they are fit to put him on, has found out
The everlasting motion in his scabbard.
I doubt not to make peace: and so for this time
My best love, and remembrance.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your poor servant. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Diego host, Philippo, and Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where will our horses meet us?

sp.speaker: Host Dieg.
sp.l: Fear not you sir,
Some half mile hence, my worship's man will stay us,
How is it with my young bloods? come, be jovial,
Let's travel like a merry flock of wild geese,
Every tongue talking.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We are very merry;
But do you know this way sir?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Is't not dangerous?
Methinks these woody thickets should harbour knaves.

sp.speaker: Host Die.
sp.l: I fear none but fair wenches: those are thieves
May quickly rob me of my good conditions
If they cry stand once: but the best is signiors
They cannot bind my hands; for any else,
They meet an equal knave, and there's my passport:
I have seen fine sport in this place, had these trees tongues,
They would tell ye pretty matters: do not you fear though
They are not every days delights.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What sport sir?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why to say true, the sport of all sports.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What was't?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Such turning up of taffetas; and you know
To what rare whistling tunes they go, far beyond
A soft wind in the shrowds: such stand there,
And down ith' tother place; such supplications
And subdivisions for those toys their honours,
One, as ye are a gentleman in this bush,
And o sweet sir, what mean ye? there's a bracelet,
And use me I beseech ye like a woman,
And her petition's heard: another scratches,
And cries she will die first, and then swoons: but certain
She is brought to life again, and does well after.
Another save mine honour, o mine honour,
My husband serves the Duke, sir, in his kitchen;
L have a cold pie for ye; fie, fie, fie gentlemen,
Will nothing satisfy ye, where's my husband?
Another cries, do ye see sir how they use me,
Is there no law for these things?

sp.speaker: The●.
sp.l: And good mine host,
Do you call these fine sports?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: What should I call 'em,
They have been so called these thousand years and upwards.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But what becomes o'th' men?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: They are stripped and bound,
Like so many Adams, with fig leaves afore 'em,
And there's their innocence.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Would we had known this?
Before we reached this place.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, there's no danger,
These are but sometimes chances.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Now we must through.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Stand to it signiors.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No it needs not,
I know the face; 'tis honest.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: What mine host:
Mine everlasting honest host.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Mass baily:
Now in the name of an ill reckoning
What make you walking this round?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: A — of this round,
And of all business too, through woods, and rascals,
They have rounded me away a dozen ducats,
Besides a fair round cloak: some of 'em knew me,
Else they had cased me like a coney too,
As they have done the rest, and I think roasted me,
For they began to baste me soundly: my young signiors,
You may thank heaven, and heartily, and hourly,
You set not out so early; ye had been smoked else
By this true hand ye had sirs, finely smoked,
Had ye been women, smockted too.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Heaven defend us.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Nay, that had been no prayer, there were those
That run that prayer out of breath, yet failed too:
There was a friar, now ye talk of prayer,
With a huge bunch of beads, like a rope of onions;
I am sure as big, that out of fear and prayer,
In half an hour wore 'em as small as bugles,
Yet he was flayed too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At what hour was this?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Some two hours since.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Do you think the passage sure now.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Yes, a rope take 'em, as it will, and bless 'em,
They have done for this day sure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Are many riffled?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: At the least a dozen,
And there left bound.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How came you free?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: A courtesy
They use out of their rogueships, to bequeath
To one, that when they give a sign from far
Which is from out of danger; he may presently
Release the rest, as I met you, I was going,
Having the sign from yonder hill to do it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas poor men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mine host, pray go untie.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let me alone for cancelling: where are they?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: In every bush like black birds, you cannot miss 'em

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I need not stalk unto 'em. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: No, they'll stand ye,
My busy life for yours sir: you would wonder
To see the several tricks, and strange behaviours
Of the poor rascals in their miseries,
One weeps, another laughs at him for weeping,
A third is monstrous angry he can laugh
And cries, go too, this is no time; he laughs still,
A fourth exhorts to patience: him a fifth man
Curses for tameness; him a friar schools,
All hoot the friar: here one sings a ballad,
And there a little curate confutes him,
And in this linsey woolsey way, that would make a dog
Forget his dinner, or an old man fire
They rub out for their ransoms: amongst the rest,
There is a little boy robbed, a fine child,
It seems a page: I must confess my pity
(As 'tis a hard thing in a man of my place)
To show compassion, stirred at him; so finely
And without noise he carries his afflictions,
And looks as if he had but dreamt of losing.
sp.stage: Enter host and Leocadia, and others as robbed.
sp.l: This boy's the glory of this robbery,
The rest but shame the action: now ye may hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Come lads, 'tis holiday: hang clothes, 'tis hot,
And sweating agues are abroad.
It seems so;
For we have met with rare physicians
To cure us of that malady.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Fine footing,
Light and deliver: now my boys: master friar,
How does your holiness, bear up man; what
A cup of neat sack now and a toast: ha, friar,
A warm plaster to your belly father,
There were a blessing now.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Ye say your mind sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Where my fine boy: my pointer.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: There's the wonder.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: A rank whore scratch their sides till the pox follow
For robbing thee, thou hast a thousand ways
To rob thyself boy, dice, and a chamber devil.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Ye are deceived sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: And thy master too boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A sweet faced boy indeed: what rogues were these?
What barbarous brutish slaves to strip this beauty?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Come hither my boy: alas! he's cold, mine host,
We must entreat your cloak.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Can ye entreat it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We do presume so much, you have other garments.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Will you entreat those too?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Your mule must too,
To the next town, you say 'tis near; in pity
You cannot see this poor boy perish.
I know ye have a better soul, we'll satisfy ye.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange foolish trick I have, but I cannot help it,
I am ever cozened with mine own commendations;
It is determined then I shall be robbed too.
To make up vantage to this dozen: here sir,
Heaven has provided ye a simple garment
To set ye off: pray keep it handsomer
Than you kept your own, and let me have it rendered,
Brushed, and discreetly folded.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Who wants a doublet?
I.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Where will you have it?
From you sir, if you please.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: O, there's the point sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My honest friends, I am sorry for your fortunes,
But that's but poor relief; here are ten ducats,
And to your distribution holy sir,
I render 'em: and let it be your care
To see 'em, as your wants are, well divided.

sp.speaker: Hos.
sp.l: Plain dealing now my friends: and father friar,
Set me the saddle right; no wringing friar,
Nor tithing to the church, these are no duties;
Scour me your conscience, if the devil tempt ye
Off with your cord, and swing him.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Ye say well sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Heaven keep your goodness.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Peace keep you, farewell friends

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Farewell light horsemen. Exit the robbed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way travel you sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: To the next town.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Do you want any thing.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Only discretion to travel at good hours,
And some warm meat to moderate this matter,
For I am most outrageous cruel hungry

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I have a stomach too such as it is
Would pose a right good pasty, I thank heaven for't.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Cheese that would break the teeth of a new handsaw,
I could endure now like an ostrich, or salt beef
That Cesar left in pickle.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Take no care,
We'll have meat for you and enough: I th' mean time
Keep you the horse way lest the fellow miss us,
We'll meet ye at the end o'th wood.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Make haste then.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: My pretty sir, till your necessities
Be full supplied, so please you trust our friendships,
We must not part.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye have pulled a charge upon ye,
Yet such a one, as ever shall be thankful.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ye have said enough: may I be bold to ask ye,
What province you were bred in? and of what parents?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye may sir: I was born in Andoluzia,
My name Francisco, son to don Henriques
De Cardinas.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Our noble neighbour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Son to don Henriques:
I know the gentleman: and by your leave sir,
I know he has no son.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: None of his own sir,
Which makes him put that right upon his brother
Don Zanchio's children: one of which I am,
And therefore do not much err.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Still ye do sir,
For neither has don Zanchio any son;
A daughter, and a rare one is heir,
Which though I never was so blessed to see,
Yet I have heard great good of.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Urge no further,
He is ashamed, and blushes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir,
If it might import you to conceal yourself,
I ask your mercy, I have been so curious:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Alas! I must ask yours sir: for these lies,
Yet they were useful ones; for by the claiming
Such noble parents, I believed your bounties
Would show more gracious: the plain truth is gentlemen,
I am don Sanchio's steward's son, a wild boy,
That for the fruits of his unhappiness,
Is fain to seek the wars.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: This is a lie too.
If I have any ears.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Mark his language,
And ye shall find it of too sweet a relish
For one of such a breed: I'll pawn my hand,
This is no boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No boy? what would you have him?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I know, no boy: I watched how fearfully,
And yet how suddenly he cured his lies,
The right wit of a woman: now I am sure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What are ye sure?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: That 'tis no boy: I'll burn in't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now I consider better, and take council,
Methinks he shows more sweetness in that face,
Than his fears dare deliver.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No more talk on't,
There hangs some great weight by it: soon at night
I'll tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come sir, whate'er you are
With us, embrace your liberty, and our helps
In any need you have.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All my poor service
Shall be at your command sir, and my prayers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let's walk a pace; hunger will cut their throats else. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Rodorigo, Mark-antonio, and a Shipmaster, two chairs set out.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Call up the master.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Here sir.Within.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Honest master,
Give order all the galleys with this tide
Fall round, and near upon us; that the next wind
We may weigh off together, and recover
The port of Barcelona, without parting.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.l: Your pleasures done sir.Within.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Signior Marc-antonio,
Till meat be ready, let's sit here and prepare
Our stomachs with discourses.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: What you please sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Pray ye answer me to this doubt.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: If I can sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Why should such plants as you are, pleasures children
That owe their blushing years to gentle objects,
Tenderly bred, and brought up in all fullness,
Desire the stubborn wars?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: In those 'tis wonder,
That make their ease their god, and nor their honour:
But noble general, my end is other,
Desire of knowledge sir, and hope of tying
Discretion to my time, which only shows me,
And not my years, a man, and makes that more.
Which we call handsome, the rest is but boys beauty,
And with the boy consumed.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ye argue well sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor do I wear my youth, as they were breeches
For object, but for use: my strength for danger,
Which is the liberal part of man, not dalliance,
The wars must be my mistress sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O signior,
You'll find her a rough wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When she is won once,
She'll show the sweeter sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You can be pleased, though
Sometimes to take a tamer?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis a truth sir,
So she be handsome, and not ill conditioned.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A soldier should not be so curious.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I can make shift with any for a heat sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Nay, there you wrong your youth too: and however
You are pleased to appear to me, which shows well signior,
A tougher soul than your few years can testify;
Yet my young sir, out of mine own experience
When my spring was, I am able to confute ye,
And say, y' had rather come to th' shock of eyes,
And boldly march up to your mistress mouth,
Then to the cannons.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's as their lading is sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: There be trenches
Fitter, and warmer for your years, and safer
Than where the bullet plays.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There's it I doubt sir.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You'll easily find that faith: but come, be liberal,
What kind of woman could you make best wars with?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are all but heavy marches.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Fie Marc-antonio,
Beauty in no more reverence?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In the sex sir,
I honour it, and next to honour, love it,
For there is only beauty; and that sweetness
That was first meant for modesty: sever it
And put it in one woman, it appears not.
'Tis of too rare a nature, she too gross
To mingle with it.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: This is a mere heresy.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Which makes 'em ever mending; for that gloss
That cozens us for beauty, is but bravery,
An outward show of things well set, no more,
For heavenly beauty, is as heaven itself sir,
Too excellent for object, and what is seen
Is but the vail then, airy clouds; grant this
It may be seen, 'tis but like stars in twinklings.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Twas no small study in their libraries
Brought you to this experience: but what think ye
Of that fair red and white, which we call beauty?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why? 'tis our creature sir, we give it 'em,
Because we like those colours, else 'tis certain
A blue face with a motley nose would do it,
And be as great a beauty, so we loved it,
That we cannot give, which is only beauty,
Is a fair mind.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: By this rule, all our choices
Are to no ends.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Except the dull end, doing.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Then all to you seem equal?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Very true sir,
And that makes equal dealing: I love any
That's worth love.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How long love ye signior?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Till I have other business.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do you never
Love steadfastly one woman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis a toil sir
Like riding in one road perpetually,
It offers no variety.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Right youth,
He must needs make a soldier; nor do you think
One woman, can love one man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes that may be,
Though it appear not often; they are things ignorant,
And therefore apted to that superstition
Of doting fondness; yet of late years signior,
That world's well mended with 'em, fewer are found now
That love at length, and to the right mark, all
Stir now as the time stirs; fame and fashion
Are ends they aim at now, and to make that love
That wiser ages held ambition;
They that cannot reach this, may love by index;
By every days surveying who best promises,
Who has done best, who may do, and who mended
May come to do again: who appears neatest
Either in new stamped clothes, or courtesies,
Done but from hand to mouth neither; nor love they these things
Longer than new are making, nor that succession
Beyond the next fair feather: take the city,
There they go to't by gold weight, no gain from 'em
All they can work by fire and water to 'em,
Profit is all they point at: if there be love
'Tis showed ye by so dark a light, to bear out
The bracks, and old stains in it, that ye may purchase
French velvet better cheap: all loves are endless.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Faith, if ye have a mistress, would she heard you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Twere but the venturing of my place, or swearing
I meant it but for argument, as schoolmen
Dispute high questions.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What a world is this
When young men dare determine what those are?
Age and the best experience ne'er could aim at.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: They were thick eyed then sir; now the print is bigger,
And they may read their fortunes without spectacles.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Did you ne'er love?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Faith yes, once after supper,
And the fit held till midnight.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Hot, or shaking.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To say true, both.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: How did ye rid it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus sir,
I laid my hand upon my heart, and blessed me,
And then said over certain charms I had learned
Against mad dogs, for love, and they are all one;
Last thought upon a windmill, and so slept,
And was well ever after.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: A rare physician,
What would your practice gain ye?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The wars ended,
I mean to use my heart, and have these fools
Cut in the head like cats, to save the kingdom,
Another inquisition.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: So old a soldier.
Out of the wars, I never knew yet practised.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall mend every day; but noble general,
Believe this, but as this you named discourses.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: O ye are a cunning gamester.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mirths and toys
To cousin time withal, for oh my troth sir,
I can love; I think, well too; well enough
And think as well of women as they are,
Pretty fantastic things, some more regardful,
And some few worth a service: I am so honest,
I with 'em all in heaven, and you know hard sir
'Twill be to get in there with their great farthingales.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Well Marc-antonio, I would not lose thy company
For the best. Galley I command.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Faith general,
If these discourses please ye, I shall fit ye
Once every day.Knock within.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Thou canst not please me better: hark, they call
Below to Didner: ye are my cabin guest,
My bosom's, so you please sir.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Your poor servant. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Let 'em have meat enough woman, half a hen;
There be old rotten pilchers, put 'em off too,
'Tis but a little new anointing of 'em,
And a strong onion, that confounds the stink.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: They call for more sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Knock a dozen eggs down,
But then beware your wenches.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: More than this too?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: Words, words, and make 'em porridg: pop 'em up
But they shall pay for cullises.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: All this is nothing;
They call for kid and partridge.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well remembered,
Where's the half falconers dog he left?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: It stinks sir,
Passed all hope that way.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Run it o'er with garlic,
And make a Roman dish on't.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Pray ye be patient,
And get provision in; these are fine gentlemen,
And liberal gentlemen; they have unde quare
No mangey muleteers, nor pinching posts
That feed upon the parings of muskmelons
And radishes, as big and tough as rafters:
Will ye be stirring in this business? here's your brother
Mine old host of Ossuva, as wise as you are,
That is, as knavish; if ye put a trick,
Take heed he do not find it.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.l: I'll be wagging.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: 'Tis for your own commodity: why wenches.
Anon for sooth.Within.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Who makes a fire there? and who gets in water?
Let Oliver go to the justice, and beseech his worship
We may have two spits going; and do you here druce,
Let him invite his worship, and his wife's worship,
To the left meat tomorrow. Enter bailiff.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Where's the kitchen?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Even at the next door signior: what old don?
We meet but seldom.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Prithee be patient hostess,
And tell me where the meat is.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Faith master baily,
How have ye done? and how man?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Good sweet hostess,
What shall we have to dinner?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: How does your woman,
And a fine woman she is and a good woman,
Lord, how you bear your years?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Is't veal, or mutton,
Beef, bacon, pork, kid, pheasant, or all these,
And are they ready all?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: The hours that have been
Between us two, the merry hours: lord!

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Hostess,
Dear hostess do but hear; I am hungry.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Ye are merrily disposed sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Monstrous hungry,
And hungry after much meat, I have brought hither
Right worshipful to pay the reckoning,
Money enough too with 'em, desire enough
To have the best meat, and of that enough too:
Come to the point sweet wench, and so I kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Ye shall have any thing, and instantly
Ere you can lick your ears, sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Portly meat,
Bearing substantial stuff, and fit for hunger:
I do beseech ye hostess first, than some light garnish,
Two pheasants in a dish, if ye have leverets,
Rather for way of ornament, than appetite
They may be looked upon, or larks: for fish,
As there is no great need, so I will I not wish ye
To serve above four dishes, but those full ones;
Ye have no cheese of Parma?

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Very old sir.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: The less will serve us, some ten pound,

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Alas sir,
We have not half these dainties.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: Peace good hostess,
And make us hope ye have.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Ye shall have all sir,

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: That may be got for money.

div.stage: Enter Diego the host, and a boy.

sp.speaker: 1. Host. Diego.
sp.l: Where's your master?
Bring me your master boy: I must have liquor
Fit for the Mermedons; no dashing now child,
No conjurings by candle light, I know all;
Strike me the oldest sack, a piece that carries
Point blank to this place boy, and batters; hostess,
I kiss thy hands through which many a round reckoning
And things of moment have had motion.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Still mind old brother.

sp.speaker: 1. Host dei.
sp.l: Set thy seller open,
For I must enter, and advance my colours
I have brought the dons indeed wench, dons with ducats,
And those dons must have dainty wine, pure Bacchus
That bleeds the life blood: what is your cure ended?

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: We shall have meat man.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Then we shall have wine man,
And wine upon wine, cut and drawn with wine.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.l: Ye shall have all, and more than all.

sp.speaker: Bayl.
sp.l: All, well then.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Away, about your business, you with her
For old acquaintance' sake, to stay your stomachExit hostess and bailiff.
And boy, be you my guide ad inferos,
For I will make a full descent in equipage.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'll show you rare wine.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Stinging gear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Divine sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: O divine boy, march, march my child, rare wine boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As in Spain sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Old, and strong too,
Oh my fine boy, clear too?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: As crystal sir, and strong as truth.

sp.speaker: 1. Host Die.
sp.l: Away boy,
I am enamoured, and I long for dalliance,
Stay nowhere child, not for thy father's blessing,
I charge thee not to save thy sister's honour,
Nor to close thy dams eyes were she a dying,
Till we arrive; and for thy recompense
I will remember thee in my will.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Ye have said sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mine host, is that apparel got ye spoke of?
Ye shall have ready money.

sp.speaker: 2. Host.
sp.l: 'Tis come in sir, he has it on sir,
And I think't will be fit, and of my credit
'Twas never worn but once sir, and for necessity
Pawned to the man I told ye of.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray bargain for it,
And I will be the paymaster.

sp.speaker: 2. Host.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And let our meat be ready when you please,
I mean as soon.

sp.speaker: 2. Host.
sp.l: It shall be presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How far stands Barcelona?

sp.speaker: 2. Host.
sp.l: But two leagues off sir,
You may be there by three o'clock .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am glad on't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Signior Francisco why I draw you hither
To this remote place, marvel not, for trust me
My innocence yet never knew ill dealing,
And as ye have a noble temper, start not
Into offence, at any thing my knowledge,
And for your special good, would be informed of,
Nor think me vainly curious.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Worthy sir,
The courtesies you and your noble brother
Even then when few men find the way to do 'em,
I mean in want, so freely showered upon me,
So truly and so timely ministered,
Must if I should suspect those minds that made 'em,
Either proclaim me an unworthy taker,
Or worse, a base believer; speak your mind sir
Freely, and what you please, I am your servant.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Then my young sir, know since our first acquaintance
Induced by circumstances that deceive not
To clear some doubts I have; nay blush not signior,
I have beheld ye narrowly; more blushes!
Sir, ye give me so much light, I find ye
A thing confessed already; yet more blushes?
You would ill cover an offence might sink ye
That cannot hide yourself; why do ye shake so?
I mean no trouble to ye; this fair hand
Was never made for hardness, nor those eyes.
Come do not hide 'em, for rough objects, hark ye,
Ye have betrayed yourself, that sigh confirms me;
Another? and a third to? than I see
These boys clothes do but pinch ye, come be liberal,
Ye have found a friend that has found you, disguise not
That loaden soul that labours to be open:
Now you must weep, I know it, for I see
Your eyes down laden to the lids, another
Manifest token that my doubts are perfect;
Yet I have found a greater; till me this
Why were these holes left open, there was an error,
A foul one my Francisco, have I caught ye?
O pretty sir, the custom of our country
Allows men none in this place: now the shower comes.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: O signior Theodoro.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: This sorrow shows so sweetly
I cannot choose but keep it company:
Take truce and speak sir: and I charge your goodness
By all those perfect hopes that point at virtue
By that remembrance these fair tears are shed for,
If any sad misfortune have thus formed ye,
That either care or counsel may redeem,
Pain, purse, or any thing within the power
And honour of free gentlemen, reveal it,
And have our labours.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I have found ye noble
And ye shall find me true; your doubts are certain,
Nor dare I more dissemble; I am a woman,
The great example of a wretched woman;
Here you must give me leave to show my sex;
And now to make ye know how much your credit
Has won upon my soul, so it please your patience,
I'll tell you my unfortunate sad story.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sit down and say on lady.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I am born sir
Of good and honest parents, rich, and noble,
And not to lie, the daughter of don Zanchio,
If my unhappy fortune have not lost me:
My name called Leocadia, even the same
Your worthy brother did the special honour
To name for beautiful; and without pride
I have been often made believe so signior;
But that's impertinent: now to my sorrows;
Not far from us a gentleman of worth,
A neighbour and a noble visitor,
Had his abode; who often met my father
In gentle sports of chase, and river hawking,
In course and riding, and with him often brought
A son of his, a young and hopeful gentleman,
Nobly trained up, in years fit for affection,
A sprightly man, of understanding excellent,
Of speech, and civil 'Haviour, no less powerful;
And of all parts, else my eyes lied, abundant:
We grew acquainted, and from that acquaintance
Nearer into affection; from affection
Into belief.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Then we durst kiss.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: But oh man, man, unconstant, careless man,
Oh subtle man, how many are thy mischiefs?
O Marc-antonio, I may curse those kisses.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What did you call him lady?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Marc-antonio,
The name to me of misery.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray forward.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: From these we bred desires sir: but lose me heaven
If mine were lustful.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I believe.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: This nearness
Made him importunate: when to save mine honour
Love having full possession of my powers,
I got a contract from him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sealed?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: And sworn too:
Which since for some offence heaven laid upon me
I lost among my moneys in the robbery,
The loss that makes me poorest: this won from him
Fool that I was, and too too credulous,
I pointed him a by-way to my chamber
The next night at an hour.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray stay there lady:
And when the night came, came he, kept he touch with ye?
Be not so shamefast: had he both your wishes?
Tell me, and tell me true, did he enjoy ye,
Were ye in one another's arms, a-bed? the contract
Confirmed in full joys there? did he lie with ye?
Answer to that; ha? did your father know this,
The good old man, or kindred privy to't?
And had ye their consents? did that night's promise
Make ye a mother?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Why do you ask so nearly?
Good sir, does it concern you any thing?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No lady,
Only the pity why you should be used so,
A little stirs me, but did he keep his promise?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: No, no signior,
Alas he never came nor never meant it,
My love was fooled, time numbered to no end,
My expectation slouted, and guess you sir,
What dor unto a doting maid this was,
What a base breaking off.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: All's well then lady;
Go forward in your story.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Not only failed sir
Which is a curse in love, and may he find it
When his affections are full winged, and ready
To stoop upon the quarry, then when all
His full hopes are in's arms: not only thus sir
But more injurious, faithless, treacherous,
Within two days fame gave him far removed
With a new love, which much against my conscience
But more against my cause, which is my hell
I must confess a fair one, a right fair one,
Indeed of admirable sweetness, daughter
Unto another of our noble neighbours
The thief called Theodosia; whose perfections
I am bound to ban for ever, curse to wrinkles,
