As heaven I hope will make 'em soon; and aches,
For they have robbed me poor unhappy wench
Of all, of all sir, all that was my glory
And left me nothing but these tears, and travel:
Upon this certain news, I quit my father
And if you be not milder in construction
I fear mine honour too; and like a page
Stole to Ossuna: from that place to civil,
From thence to Barcelona I was travelling
When you overtook my misery, in hope to hear of
Galleys bound up for Italy; for never
Will I leave off the search of this bad man
This filcher of affections, this love pedlar,
Nor shall my curses cease to blast her beauties
And make her name as wand'ring as her nature
Till standing face to face before their lusts
I call heavens justice down.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: This shows too angry
Nor can it be her fault she is beloved,
If I give meat, must they that eat it surfeit?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: She loves again sir, there's the mischief of it
And in despite of me to drown my blessings
Which she shall dear know.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ye are too violent.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: She has devils in her eyes, to whose devotion
He offers all his service.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Who can say
But she may be forsaken too? he that once wanders
From such a perfect sweetness, as you promise
Has he not still the same rule to deceive?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: No, no they are together, love together
Passed all deceit of that side; sleep together,
Live, and delight together, and such deceit
Give me in a wild desert.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By your leave lady
I see no honour in this cunning.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Honour?
True, none of her part, honour, she deserves none,
'Tis ceased with wandering ladies such as she is,
So bold and impudent.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I could be angry
Extremely angry now beyond my nature
And 'twere not for my pity: what a man
Is this to do these wrongs: believe me lady
I know the maid, and know she is not with him.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I would you knew she were in heaven.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And so well know her
That l think you are cozened.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: So I say sir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I mean in her behaviour
For trust my faith so much I dare adventure for her credit
She never yet delighted to do wrong:

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: How can she then delight in him; dare she think
Be what she will, as excellent as angels
My love so fond, my wishes so indulgent
That I must take her prewnings; stoop at that
She has tired upon: no sir, I hold my beauty
Wash but these sorrows from it; of a sparkle
As right and rich as hers, my means as equal,
My youth as much unblown: and for our worths
And weight of virtue.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Do not task her so far.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By heaven she is cork, and clouds, light, light sir, vapour
But I shall find her out, with all her witchcrafts,
Her paintings, and her powncings: for 'tis art
And only art preserves her, and mere spells
That work upon his powers: let her but show me
A ruined cheek like mine, that holds his colour
And writes but sixteen years in spite of sorrows
An unbathed body, smiles, that give but shadows
And wrinkle not the face: besides she is little
A demi dame that, that makes no object.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Nay,
Than I must say you err: for credit me
I think she is taller than yourself.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Why let her
It is not that shall mate me: I but ask
My hands may reach unto her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Gentle lady
'Tis now ill time of further argument,
For I perceive your anger void of council,
Which I could wish more temperate.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Pray forgive me
If I have spoken uncivilly: they that look on
See more than we that play: and I beseech ye
Impute it loves offence, not mine; whose torments,
If you have ever loved, and found my crosses
You must confess are seldom tied to patience,
Yet I could wish I had said less.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No harm then;
Ye have made a full amends; our company
You may command, so please you in your travels
With all our faith and furtherance; let it be so.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Ye make too great an offer.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Then it shall be
Go in and rest yourself, our wholesome diet
Will be made ready straight: but hark ye lady
One thing I must entreat, your leave, and sufferance
That these things may be open to my brother
For more respect and honour.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And do not change this habit by no means
Unless ye change yourself.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Which must not yet be.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: It carries ye concealed and safe.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I am counselled. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's done?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why all we doubted; 'tis a woman,
And of a noble strain too, guess.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You have heard often of her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stay I think not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Indeed ye have; 'tis the fair Leocadia
Daughter unto don Zanchio, our noble neighbour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: 'Tis she sir of my credit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia,
Pish Leocadia, it must not be.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: It must be, or be nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wonder, Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The damsel Leocadia
I guessed it was a woman, and a fair one
I see it through her shape, transparent plain
But that it should be she; tell me directly.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By heavens 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By heaven then 'tis a sweet one.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: That's granted too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But hark ye, hark ye sister,
How came she this disguised?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I'll tell you that too
As I came on the selfsame ground, so used too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By the same man?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The same too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As I live
You lovers have fine fancies,
Wondrous fine ones.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Pray heaven you never make one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith I know not,
But in that mind I am, I had rather cobble,
'Tis a more Christian trade: pray tell me one thing
Are not you two now monstrous jealous
Of one another?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: She is much of me
And has railed at me most unmercifully
And to my face, and of my conscience
Had she but known me, either she or I
Or both, had parted with strange faces
She was in such a fury.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia?
Does she speak handsomely?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Wondrous well sir
And all she does becomes her, even her anger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How seemed she when you found her?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Had you seen
How sweetly fearful her pretty self
Betrayed herself, how neat her sorrow showed,
And in what handsome phrase she put her story,
And as occasion stirred her how she started
Though roughly, yet most aptly into anger
You would have wondered.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Does she know ye?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: No.
Nor must not by no means.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How stands your difference?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I'll tell ye that some fitter time, but trust me
My Marckantonio has too much to answer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: May I take knowledge of her?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes she is willing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray use her as she is, with all respects then,
For she is a woman of a noble breeding.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ye shall not find me wanting.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way bears she?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Our way, and to our end.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am glad on't; hark ye,
She keeps her shape? Enter Leocadia.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yes, and I think by this time
Has mewed her old.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She is here: by heaven a rare one,
An admirable sweet one, what an eye
Of what a full command she bears, how gracious
All her aspect shows; bless me from a favour
I am not well o'th sudden.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Noble friends
Your meat and all my service waits upon ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ye teach us manners lady; all which service
Must now be mine to you, and all to poor too;
Blush not, we know ye; for by all our faiths
With us your honour is in sanctuary
And ever shall be.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I do well believe it,
Will ye walk nearer sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo
sp.l: She shows still fairer,
Younger in every change, and clearer, neater;
I know not, I may fool myself, and finely
Nourish a wolf to eat my heart out; certain
As she appears now, she appears a wonder,
A thing amazes me; what would she do then
In woman's helps, in ornaments apt for her
And deckings to her delicacy? without all doubt
She would be held a miracle; nor can I think
He has forsaken her: say what she please,
I know his curious eye, or say he had,
Put case he could be so boy-blind and foolish,
Yet still I fear she keeps the contract with her
Not stolen as she affirms, nor lost by negligence,
She would lose herself first, 'tis her life, and there
All my hopes are dispatched; oh noble love
That thou couldst be without this jealousy,
Without this passion of the heart, how heavenly
Would thou appear upon us? Come what may come
I'll see the end on't: and since chance has cast her
Naked into my refuge, all I can
She freely shall command, except the man. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Don Pedro, do you think assuredly
The galleys will come round to Barcelona
Within these two days?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Without doubt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And think ye
He will be with 'em certainly?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He is sir
I saw him at their setting off.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Must they needs
Touch there for water as you say?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: They must sir
And for fresh meat too: few or none go by it
Beside so great a fleet must needs want trimming
If they have met with foul seas, no harbour
On this side, Spain, is able without danger
To Moor 'em, but that haven.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Are the wars
His only end?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: So he professes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bears he
Any command amongst 'em?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Good regard
With all; which quickly will prefer him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pray sir tell me,
And as you are a gentleman be liberal.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I will sir, and most true.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who saw ye with him?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: None but things like himself; young soldiers
And gentlemen desirous to seek honour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Was there no woman there, nor, none disguised
That might be thought a woman in his language?
Did he not let slip something of suspicion
Touching that wanton way.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Believe me sir
I neither saw, nor could suspect that face
That might be doubted woman's, yet I am sure
Aboard him I see all that passed, and 'tis impossible
Among so many high set bloods there should be
A woman, let her close herself within a cockle,
But they would open her, he must not love
Within that place alone, and therefore surely
He would not be so foolish, had he any,
To trust her there; for his discourse, 'twas ever
About his business, war, or mirth to make us
Relish 'a can of wine well; when he spoke private
'T was only the remembrance of his service,
And hope of your good prayers for his health sir,
And so I gave him to the seas.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I thank ye,
And now am satisfied, and to prevent
Suspicions that may nourish dangers signior,
For I have told you how the mad Alphenso
Chafes like a stag i'th toil, and bends his fury
'Gainst all, but his own ignorance; I am determined
For peace' sake and the preservation
Of my yet untouched honour, and his cure
Myself to seek him there, and bring him back
As testimony of an unsought injury
By either of our actions; that the world
And he if he have reason, may see plainly
Opinion is no perfect guide; nor all fames
Founders of truths: in the mean time this courtesy
I must entreat of you sir, be myself here
And as myself command my family.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye lay too much trust on me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis my love sir,
I will not be long from ye; if this question
Chance to be called upon ere my return
I leave your care to answer; so farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye take a wise way; all my best endeavours
Shall labour in your absence; peace go with ye. Exit leo.
A noble honest gentleman, free hearted
And of an open faith, much loving, and much loved,
And father of that goodness only malice
Can truly stir against; what dare befall
Till his return I'll answer. Exit Ped.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Walk off sirrah
But keep yourself within my call?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And stir my horse for taking cold: within there,
Hoa people; you that dwell there, my brave signior
What are ye all asleep ? is't that time with ye?
I'll ring a little louder.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sir who seek ye?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Not you sir; where's your master?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I serve no man
In way of pay sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Where's the man o'th house then?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What would you have with him sir?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Do you stand here sir
To ask men questions when they come?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I would sir
Being his friend, and hearing such alarms
Know how men come to visit him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ye shall sir,
Pray tell his mightiness here is a gentleman
By name Alphonso, would entreat his conference
About affairs of state sir, are ye answered?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I must be sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Stay, set me down, stay signior,
You must stay, and ye shall stay.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Meaning me sir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Yes you sir, you I mean, I mean you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Well sir,
Why should I stay?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: There's reason.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Reason sir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I reason sir
My wrong is greatest, and I will be served first,
Call out the man of fame?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How served sir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Thus sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: But not before me.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Before all the world sir
As my case stands.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I have lost a daughter sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I have lost another worth five score of her sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ye must not tell me so.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I have, and hark ye?
Make it up five score more: call out the fellow,
And stand you by sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: This is the mad morris.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: And I stand by?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I say stand by, and do it.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Stand by among thy lungs.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Turn presently
And say thy prayers, thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I scorn thee
And scorn to say my prayers more than thou dost,
Mine is the most wrong, and my daughter dearest
And mine shall first be righted.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Shall be righted.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A third may live I see, pray hear me gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Shall be.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ay, shall be righted.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Now?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Before I stir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Before me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Before any.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Dost thou consider what thou sayest? hast thou friends here
Able to quench my anger, or persuade me
After I have beaten thee into one main bruist
And made thee spend thy state in rotten apples,
Thou canst at length be quiet, shall I kill thee
Divide thee like a rotten pompion,
And leave thee stinking to posterity,
There's not the least blow I shall give; but does this
Urge me no further: I am first.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'll hang first.
No goodman glory, 'tis not your bravadoes,
Your punctual honour, nor soldadoship.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Set me a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Let him sally.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Lined with your quirks of carriage and discretion
Can blow me off my purpose. Where's your credit
With all your school points now? your decent arguing
And apt time for performing: where are these toys,
These wise ways, and most honourable courses,
To take revenge? how dar'st thou talk of killing,
Or think of drawing any thing but squirts
When lechery has dry foundered thee?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Nearer yet,
That I may spit him down: thou lookest like a man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I would be thought so sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Prithee do but take me,
And fling me upon that puppy.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Do for heaven's sake,
And see but how I'll hug him.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Yet take warning.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Faith gentlemen, this is a needless quarrel.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And do you desire to make one?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As a friend sir,
To tell you all this anger is but lost sir,
For Leonardo is from home.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, no sir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Indeed he is.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Where dare he be, but here sir,
When men are wronged, and come for satisfactions.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: It seems he has done none sir, for his business
Clear of those cares, hath carried him for sometime
To Barcelona; if he had been guilty,
I know he would have stayed, and cleared all difference
Either by free confession, or his sword.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: This must not be.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Sure, as I live, it is sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sure, as we all live,
He's run away for ever: Barcelona,
Why? 'tis the key for Italy, from whence
He stole first hither.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And having found his knaveries
Too gross to be forgiven, and too open,
He has found the same way back again: I believe too
The good grass gentleman, for his own ease,
Has taken one oth' pillows: is not his stuff sold.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I fear his worship's shoes too; to escape us,
I do not think he has a dish within doors,
A louse left of his lineage.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Ye are too wide sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Or one poor wooden spoon,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Come in and see sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'll see his house on fire first.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Then be pleased sir
To give better censure.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will after him,
And search him like concealed land; but I'll have him,
And though I find him in his shrift, I'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'll bear ye company.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Pray have a care then,
A most especial care, indeed a fear,
Ye do not anger me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I will observe ye,
And if I light upon him handsomely.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Kill but a piece of him, leave some Alphonso
For your poor friends.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I fear him not for all this.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Shall we first go home,
For it may prove a voyage, and dispose
Of things there; heaven knows what may follow.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: No,
I'll kill him in this shirt I have on: let things
Govern themselves, I am master of my honour
At this time, and no more; let wife, and land,
Lie lay till I return.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I say amen to't:
But what care for our moneys?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will not spend
Above three shillings, till his head be here,
Four is too great a sum for all his fortunes.
Come take me up instantly.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Farewell to you sir,
And if your friend be in a featherbed,
Sowed up to shroud his fears, tell him 'tis folly,
For no course but his voluntary hanging
Can get our pardons. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: These I think would be
Offence enough, if their own indiscretions
Would suffer 'em: two of the old seditions,
When they want enemies, they are their own foes:
Were they a little wiser, I should doubt 'em:
Till when I'll ne'er break sleep, nor suffer hunger
For any harm he shall receive: for 'tis as easy
If he be guilty, to turn these two old men
Upon their own throats, and look on, and live still.
As 'tis to tell five pound: a great deal sooner,
And so I'll to my meat, and then to hawking. Exit.

div.head: Scaena i.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Sir, this is compliment; I pray you leave me.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir, is it not?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Why? I would only see the town.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And only that I come to show you.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Which I can see without you.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: So you may
Plainly, not safely: for such difference
As you have seen betwixt the sea and earth
When waves rise high, and land would beat 'em back
As fearful of invasion; such we find
When we land here at Barcelona.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Besides our general of the galleys, fearing
Your hasty nature, charged me not return
Without you safe.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O sir, that Rodorigo
Is noble, and he does mistake my temper.
There is not in the world, a mind less apt
To conceive wrongs, or do 'em; has he seen me
In all this voyage, in the which he pleases
To call me friend, let slip a hasty word?
'Slight sir: yonder is a lady veiled,
For properness, beyond comparison,
And sure her face is like the rest: we'll see't.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Why? you are hasty sir already: know you
What 'tis you go about.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Yes, I would see
The woman's face.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By heaven you shall not do't:Job. eacon ready to shool off a pistol.
You do not know the custom of the place:
To draw that curtain here, though she were mean,
Is mortal.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Is it? earth must come to earth
At last, and by my troth, I'll try it sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I must hold you fast. By all the faith
That can be placed in man, 'tis an attempt
More dangerous than death: 'tis death and shame:
I know the lady well.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Is she a lady?
I shall the more desire to see her sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: She is Alanso's wife, the governor,
A noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Then let me go,
If I can win her, you and I will govern
This town sir, fear it not, and we will alter
These barbarous customs then; for every lady
Shall be seen daily, and seen over too.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, do not jest, nor let your passions bear you
To such wild enterprises: hold you still,
For as I have a soul, you shall not do't.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: She is a lady of unblemished fame,Above.
And here to offer that affront, were base:
Hold on your way, and we will see the town,
And overlook the ladies.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I am schooled,
And promise you I will: but good sir, see,
She will pass by us now; I hope I may
Salute her thus far off.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is foot, are you mad?
'Twill be as ill as th'other.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: What's the matter?
What would that fellow have?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good sir forbear,

sp.speaker: 1. atte.
sp.l: It seems you are new landed: would you beg
Any thing here?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Yes sir, all happiness
To that fair lady, as I hope.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Marc-antonio.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Her face, which needs no hiding: I would beg
A sight of.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now go on, for 'tis too late
To keep this from a tumult.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: Sirrah, you
Shall see a fitter object for your eyes,
Than a fair lady's face.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: For heaven's sake, raise not
A quarrel in the streets for me.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: Slip in then;
This is your door.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Will you needs quarrel then?

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: We must, or suffer
This outrage: is't not all your minds sirs, speak?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Then I do beseech ye, let my lord
Not think the quarrel about me; for 'tis not. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: See, haply some of our galley soldiers
Are come ashore.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: Come on sir, you shall see
Faces enough.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Some one of you call to
Our general, the whole roar of the town
Comes in upon us.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I have seen sir better
Perhaps, then that was covered; and will yet
See that, or spoil yours.Fight.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: On: why start you back?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas sir, they are fighting.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Let's begone,
See, see, a handsome man struck down.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Ho general,
Look out, Antonio is in distress.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Antonio! 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Rod. within.
sp.l: Ho, governor make a shot into the town,
I'll part you: bring away AntonioA shot.
Into my Cabin. Exit attendants and townsmen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will do that office.
I fear it is the last, that I shall do him.

div.stage: Exit soldiers and gentlemen with Marckantonio.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The last, why will he die?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Since I have found him: happiness leave me,
When I leave him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why Theodosia?
My sister; wake: alas, I grieved but now
To see the streets so full; and now I grieve
To see 'em jest so empty I could wish,
Tumult himself were here, that yet at least
Amongst the band, I might espy some face
So pale and fearful, that would willingly
Embrace an errand for a cordial,
Or aquavitae, or a cup of sack,
Or a physician. But to talk of these
She breathes: stand up, oh Theodosia,
Speak but as thou wert wont, give but a sigh,
Which is but the most unhappy piece of life,
And I will ever after worship and build
Apply myself to grief; prepare and build
Altars to sorrow.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O Philippo, help me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do; these are my arms; Philippo's arms,
Thy brother's arms that hola thee up.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You help me
To life: but I would see Antonio
That's dead.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou shalt see any thing; how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Better, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why that's well: call up
Thy senses, and uncloud thy covered spirits.
How now?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Recovered: but Antonio,
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will find him: art thou well?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Perfectly well, saving the miss of him;
And I do charge you here, by our alliance,
And by the love which would have been betwixt us,
Knew we no kindred; by that killing fear,
Mingled with twenty thousand hopes and doubts,
Which you may think, placed in a lover's heart,
And in a virgin's too, when she wants help,
To grant me your assistance, to find out
This man alive, or dead; and I will pay you
In service, tears, or prayers, a world of wealth:
But other treasure, I have none: alas!
You men have strong hearts; but we feeble maids
Have tender eyes, which only given be
To blind themselves, crying for what they see.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why dost thou charge me thus? have I been found
Slow to perform, what I could but imagine
Thy wishes were; have I at any time
Tendered a business of mine own, beyond
A vanity of thine? have I not been
As if I were a senseless creature, made
To serve thee without power of questioning,
If so, why fearest thou?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, then let's go; where's Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where's Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia,
This tumult made the streets as dead as night,
A man may talk as freely: what's become
Of Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: She's run away.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Begone, and let us never more behold
Each others face, till we may both together
Fasten our eyes on her: accursed be
Those tender cozening names of charity,
And natural affection, they have lost
Me only by observing them, what cost
Travel, and fruitless wishes may in vain
Search through the world, but never find again.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good sir be patient, I have done no fault
Worthy this banishment.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yes, Leocadia,
The lady so distressed, who was content
To lay her story, and to lay her heart
As open as her story to yourself,
Who was content, that I should know her sex,
Before dissembled, and to put herself
Into my conduct, when I undertook
Safely to guard, is in this tumult lost.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And can I help it sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No, would thou couldst,
You might have done, but for that scale religion
You woman bear to swoonings, you do pick
Your times to faint, when somebody is by:
Bound or by nature, or by love, or service
To raise you from that well dissembled death:
Inform me but of one that has been found
Dead in her private chamber by herself,
Where sickness would no more forbear, than here,
And I will quit the rest for her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I know not
What they may do, and how they may dissemble;
But by my troth, I did not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By my troth,
Would I had tried; would I had let thee lain,
And followed her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I would you had done so
Rather, then been so angry: where's Antonio?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why dost thou vex me with these questions?
I'll tell thee where, he's carried to the galleys,
There to be chained, and row, and beat, and row
With knotted ropes, and pizzles; if he swoon,
He has a dotes of biscuit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I am glad
He is alive.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Was ever man thus troubled,
Tell me where Leocadia is?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good brother be not so hasty, and I think I can:
You found no error in me, when I first ▪
Told you she was a woman, and believe me
Something I have found out, which makes me think,
Nay, almost know so well, that I durst swear
She followed hurt Antonio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What do we
sp.stage: Enter the governor, two attendees, and the townsmen.
sp.l: Then lingering here; we will aboard the galleys
And find her.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Made he a shot into the town?

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: He did sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Call back those gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: The governor, commands you back.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will obey him sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You gave him cause so shoot, I know; he is
So far from rash offence, and holds with me
Such curious friendship: could not one of you
Have called me while 'twas doing, such an uproar,
Before my door too?

sp.speaker: 1. Townsm.
sp.l: By my troth sir, we were so busy in the public cause, of our own
Private falling out, that we forgotten it; at home we see now
You were not, but as soon as the shot made us fly, we ran
Away as fast as we could to seek your honour.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: 'Twas gravely done; but no man tells the cause
Or chance, or what it was that made you differ.

sp.speaker: 1. Towns.
sp.l: For my part sir, if there were any that I knew
Of, the shot drove it out of my head: do you know any neighbours.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Not we, not we.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Not well nor can you tell.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: No other cause,
But the old quarrel betwixt the town and the galleys.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Come nearer gentlemen: what are your names?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My name Philippo.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And mine Theodoro.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Strangers you are it seems.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Newly arrived.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Then you are they begun this tumult.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Speak one of you.

sp.speaker: 1. attend
sp.l: They are not, I can quiet 'em.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Yet we saw part, and an unhappy part
Of this debate, a long sought friend of ours
Struck down for dead, and born unto the galleys,
His name is Marc-antonio.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And another
Of our own company, a gentleman
Of noble birth, besides accompanied
With all the gifts of nature, ravished hence?
We know not how, in this dissension.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Get you home all, and work; and when I hear
You meddle with a weapon any more
But those belonging to your trades, I'll lay you
Where your best customers shall hardly find you. Exit townsmen.
I am sorry gentlemen, I troubled you,
Being both strangers; by your tongues, and looks,
Of worth: to make ye some part of amends
If there be any thing in this poor town
Of Barcelona that you would command,
Command me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir, this wounded gentleman,
If it might please you, if your power and love
Extend so far, I would be glad to wish
Might be removed into the town for cure:
The galleys stay not, and his wound I know
Cannot endure a voyage.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir, he shall,
I warrant you; go call me hither sirrah,
One of my other servants. Exit 1. attendant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And besides.
The gentleman we lost, signior Francisco,
Shall he be rendered too.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: And he sir too: go sirrah, bear this ring
To Rodorigo, my most noble friend,
The general of the galleys: tell him this. Exit servant:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Now we shall have 'em both.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Blessed be thy thoughts
For apprehending this: blessed be thy breath
For uttering it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Come gentlemen, you shall
Enter my roof: and I will send for surgeons,
And you shall see your friends here presently.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: His name was Marc-antonio.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I know it,
And have sent word so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Did you not forget
Francisco's name?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nor his: you're truly welcome,
To talk about it more, were but to say
The same word often over: you are welcome. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Mark-antonio, carried. Leocadia following, and the servant. 2 soldiers carrying him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: This is the house sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Enter it, I pray you,
For I am faint, although I think my wound
Be nothing. Soldiers, leave us now: I thank you.

sp.speaker: 1. soldier
sp.l: Heaven send you health sir.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Let me lead you in.

sp.speaker: Mark.
sp.l: My wounds not in my feet; I shall entreat 'em
I hope to bear me so far. Exit.

sp.speaker: 2. soldier
sp.l: How seriously these land men fled, when our general made a
Shot, as if he had been a warning to call 'em to their hall.

sp.speaker: 1. soldier
sp.l: I cannot blame 'em: what a man have they now in the
Town, able to maintain a tumult, or uphold a matter out
Of square if need be: oh the quiet hurly-burlies that I
Have seen in this town, when we have fought four hours
Together, and not a man amongst us so impertinent or
Modest to ask why? but now the pillars that bore
Up this blessed town in that regular debate, and
Scambling, are dead, the more's the pity.

sp.speaker: 2. soldier
sp.l: Old Ignatio lives still.

sp.speaker: 1. soldier
sp.l: Yes, I know him: he will do prettily well at a man's liver:
But where is there a man now living in the town
That hath a steady hand, and understands anatomy
Well? if it come to a particular matter of the lungs,
Or the spleen, why? alas Ignatio is to seek; are
There any such men left as I have known, that
Would say they would hit you in this place? is there
Ever a good heartist, or a member percer, or a
Small-gut man left in the town, answer
Me that.

sp.speaker: 2. soldier
sp.l: Mass, I think there be not.

sp.speaker: 1. soldier
sp.l: No, I warrant thee. Come, come, 'tis time
We were at the galleys. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter governor, Eugenia, Mark-antonio, Philippo, Theodosia, Leocadia, attendants.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir, you may know by what I said already,
You may command my house; but I must beg
Pardon to leave you, if the public business
Forced me not from you, I myself should call it
Unmannerly: but good sir, do you give it
A milder name: it shall not be an hour
Ere I return.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Sir, I was ne'er so poor
In my own thoughts, as that I want a means
To require this with.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir, within this hour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: This the lady that I quarrelled for:
Oh lust, if wounds cannot restrain thy power,
Let shame: nor do I feel my hurt at all,
Nor is it ought, only I was well beaten:
If I pursue it, all the civil world
That ever did imagine the content
Found in the band of man and wife unbroke,
The reverence due to households, or the blemish
That may be stuck upon posterity
Will catch me, bind me, burn upon my forehead,
This is the wounded stranger, that received
For charity into a house, attempted:
I will not do it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, how do you now?
That you walk off.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Worse madam, than I was;
But it will over.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sit, and rest a while.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Where are the surgeons?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, it is their manner,
When they have seen the wound especially,
The patient being of worth, to go consult,
Which they are now at in another room,
About the dressing.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, I do feel
Myself not well.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: How do you sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Will you drink waters?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: No good madam, 'tis not
So violent upon me; nor I think
Any thing dangerous: but yet there are
Some things that sit so heavy on my conscience
That will perplex my mind, and stop my cure,
So that unless I utter 'em. A scratch
Here on my thumb will kill me: gentlemen,
I pray you leave the room, and come not in
Yourselves, or any other till I have
Opened myself to this most honoured lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We will not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O blessed! he will discover now
His love to me.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Now he will tell the lady
Our contract. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I do believe he will confess to me
The wrong he did a lady in the streets;
But I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, I perceive
Myself grow worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shall I call back your friends?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O no; but ere I do impart
What burdens me so sore, let me entreat you,
(For there is no trust in these surgeons)
To look upon my wound; it is perhaps
My last request: but tell me truly too,
That must be in: how far you do imagine
Ir will have power upon me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: For heaven's sake, softly: o, I must needs lay
My head down easily, whilst you do it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Do sir,
'Tis but an ordinary blow; a child
Of mine has had a greater, and been well;
Are you faint hearted?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why do you sigh?
There is no danger in the world in this;
I wonder it should make a man sit down;
What do you mean, why do you kiss my breasts?
Lift up your head, your wound, may well endure it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O madam, may I not express affection,
Dying-affection too I fear, to those
That do me favours, such as this of yours.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you mean so, 'tis well; but what's the business
Lies on your conscience?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will tell you madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Tell me, and laugh?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But I will tell you true
Though I do laugh, I know as well as you
My wound is nothing, nor the power of earth
Could lay a wound upon me, in your presence,
That I could feel; but I do laugh to think
How covertly, how far beyond the reach
Of men, and wise-men too, we shall deceive 'em,
Whilst they imagine I am talking here
With that short breath I have, ready to swoon
At every full point; you my ghostly mother
To hear my sad confession, you and I
Will on that bed within, prepared for me,
Debate the matter privately.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Forbear,
Thou wert but now as welcome to this house
As certain cures to sick men, and just now
This sudden alteration makes thee look
Like plagues come to infect it; if thou knewest
How loathsome thou wilt be, thou wouldst entreat
These walls, or posts to help thee to a hurt,
Passed thy dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gentle madam
Call 'em not in?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I will not ye, this place
I know to be within the reach of tongue,
And ears, thou canst not force me; therefore hear me
What I will tell thee quickly, thou art born
To end some way more disesteemed than this,
Or which is worse, to die of this hurt yet,
Come gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good madam.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Madam how is't? is Marc-antonio well?
Methinks your looks are altered, and I see
A strange distemper in you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I am wrought
By that dissembling man, that fellow worth
Nothing but kicking.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Gentle madam speak
To me alone, let not them understand
His fault, he will repent it I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I'll tell it you in private.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Marc-antonio,
How do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stand further off I pray you
Give me some air.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good brother, will he scape,
The surgeons say there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Scape?
No doubt he will.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Alas will he not leave
This trying all; madam, I do beseech you
Let me but speak to him, you and these by,
And I dare almost promise you to make him
Show himself truly sorrowful to you, besides a story I shall open to you,
Not put in so good words but in itself
So full of chance, that you will easily
Forgive my tediousness, and be well pleased
With that so much afflicts me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Good sir do.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And I desire no interruption
Of speech may trouble me, till I have said
What I will quickly do.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What will she say?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Come gentlemen, I pray you lend your ears,
And keep your voices.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Signior Marc-antonio
How do you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O the surgeons.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Let me tell you
Who know as well as you, you do dissemble,
It is no time to do so; leave the thoughts
Of this vain world, forget your flesh and blood,
And make your spirit an untroubled way
To pass to what it ought.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You're not in earnest?
Why I can walk sir, and am well.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: 'Tis true
That you can walk, and do believe you're well:
It is the nature, as your surgeons say
Of these wounds, for a man to go, and talk,
Nay merrily, till his last hour, his minute:
For heaven's sake sir, sit down again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas
Where are the surgeons?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Sir, they will not come,
If they should dress you, you would die they say
Ere one told twenty; trouble not your mind,
Keep your head warm, and do not stir you body,
And you may live an hour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O heavens, an hour?
Alas, it is too little to remember
But half the wrongs that I have done; how short
Then for contrition, and how least of all
For satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But you desire
To satisfy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heaven knows I do.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Then know
That I am he, or she, or what you will
Most wronged by you; your Leocadia,
I know you must remember me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That lost her friends, that lost her father's house,
That lost her fame, in losing of her sex,
With these strange garments, there is no excuse
To hinder me, it is within your power
To give me satisfaction; you have time
Left in this little piece of life to do it:
Therefore I charge you for your conscience' sake,
And for our fame, which I would fain have live
When both of us are dead; to celebrate
That contract; which you have both sealed and sworn
Yet ere you die, which must be hastily
Heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas, the sting of conscience
To deathward for our faults: draw nearer all
And hear what I unhappy man shall say;
First madam I desire your pardon; next
(I fell my spirits fail me) gentlemen
Let me shake hands with you, and let's be friends,
For I have done wrong upon wrong so thick
I know not where, that every man methinks
Should be mine enemy; forgive me both.
Lastly 'tis true (O I do feel the power
Of death seize on me) that I was contracted
By seal and oath to Leocadia;
(I must speak fast, because I fear my life
Will else be shorter than my speech would be)
But 'tis impossible to satisfy
You Leocadia, but by repentance,
Though I can dyingly, and boldly say
I know not your dishonour, yet that was
Your virtue, and not mine, you know it well;
But herein lies th' impossibility,
Oh Theodosia, Theodosia
I was betrothed to Theodosia
Before I ever saw thee; heaven forgive me
She is my wife this half hour whilst I live.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: That's I, that's I, I'm Theodosia,
Hear me a little now, who have not suffered
Disgrace at all methinks, since you confess
What I so long have sought for, here is with me
Philippo too, my brother.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad;
All happiness to him; come let me kiss thee
Beg pardon of that maid for my offence,
And let me further, with a dying breath
Tell in thine ear, the rest of my desires.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I am afraid they will all four turn women
If we hold longer talk.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Alas there is
No hope for me; that's Theodosia
And that her brother, I am only sorry
I was beholding to 'em; I will search
Over the world, as careless of my fortunes,
As they of me, till I can meet a curse
To make these almost-killing sorrows worse. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir, as I live she lied, only to draw
A just confession from you, which she hath
A happy one for me, ask of this lady,
Ask of my brother.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, she did dissemble,
Your wound is nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Leocadia's gone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Rise up, and stir yourself, 'tis but amazement
And your imagination that afflicts you,
Look you sir now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The surgeons do not come, because they swear
It needs no dressing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: You shall talk with 'em
Within, for your own fancy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where's your brother and Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Within belike.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I feel myself methinks as well as ever.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Keep then your mind so too; I do forgive
The fault you did to me; but here is one
Must not be wronged hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Neither shall she
When I make jests of oaths again, or make
My lust play with religion, when I leave
To keep true joys for her, and yet within
Myself true sorrow for my passed deeds
May I want grace, when I would fain repent,
And find a great and sudden punishment. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where is mine host, did not he see him neither?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Not I, i'faith sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor the muleteer?

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Nay he is passed seeing, unless it be in's sleep,
By this time; all his visions were the pots,
Three hours since sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Which way should she take?
Nay, look you now; do you all stand still? good god
You might have lighted on him, now, this instant?
For love's sake seek him out, whoever find him
I will reward his fortune as his diligence;
Get all the town to help, that will be hired,
Their pains I'll turn to an annual holiday,
If it shall chance, but one bring word of her,
Pray you about it.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Her sir? who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: (I had forgotten myself) the page I meant
That came along with us.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He you give the clothes too?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I give the clothes to; rascal.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Nay good sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Why dost thou mention, or upbraid my courtesies slave?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: For your honour sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wretch; I was honoured,
That she would wear 'em (He, I would say) is death?
Go, get, and find him out, or never see me,
I shall betray my love ere I possess it,
Some star direct me, or ill planet strike me. Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Best to divide.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I'll this way.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: And I this.

sp.speaker: Dieg.
sp.l: Ay, as you, find him for a real.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My course is now directly to some pie-house
I know the page's compass.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I think rather
The smock side of the town, the surer harbour
At his years to put in.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: If I do find
The hungry haunt, I take him by the teeth now.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: I by the tail, yet I as you.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: No more. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear Leocadia, where canst thou be fled
Thus like a spirit hence? and in a moment?
What cloud can hide thee from my following search
If yet thou art a body? sure she hath not
Ta'en any house? she did too late leave one
Where all humanity of a place received her,
And would (If she had stayed) have helped to right
The wrong her fortune did her; yet she must
Be interred somewhere, or be found, no street,
Lane, passage, corner, turn, hath scaped enquiry:
If her despair had ravished her to air
She could not yet be rarefied soEnter Incube.
But some of us should meet her? though their eyes
Perhaps be leaden, and might turn; mine would
Strike out a lightning for her, and divide
A mist as thick as ever darkness was,
Nay see her through a quarry; they do lie,
Lie grossly that say love is blind: by him,
And heaven they lie; he has a sight can pierce
Through ivory as clear as it were horn,
And reach his object.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: Sir he's found, he's found.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha? where? But reach that happy note again
And let it relish truth, thou art an angel.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: He's here; fast by sir, calling for a boat
To go aboard the galleys.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Where, where; hold thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Inc.
sp.l: He might ha' kept this now, I had naught to show for 't
If he had had the wit to have gone from is word,
These direct men, they are no men of fashion,
Talk what you will, this is a very smelled. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Upon your art sir, and your faith to assist it
Shall I believe you then his wounds not mortal?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Sir 'tis not worth your question; less your fear.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You do restore me sir, I pray you accept
This small remembrance of a father's thanks
For so assured a benefit.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir I can spare it, and must not believe
But that your fortune may receive 't, except
You'ld ha' me think you live not by your practice.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: I crave your pardon sir; you teach me manners.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I crave your love and friendship, and require
As I have made now, both myself and business
A portion of your care, you will but bring me
Under the person of a called assistant
To his next opening, where I may but see him,
And utter a few words to him in private,
And you will merit me; for I am loath
Since here I have not to appear myself,
Or to be known unto the governor,
Or make a tumult of my purpose.

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Neither
I hope will be your need sir; I shall bring you
Both there, and off again without the hazard. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will you not hear me?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I have heard so much
Will keep me deaf for ever; no, Mark-antony
After thy sentence, I may hear no more,
Thou hast pronounced me dead.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Appeal to reason,
She will reprieve you from the power of grief,
Which rules but in her absence; hear me say
A sovereign message from her, which in duty,
And love to your own safety, you ought hear:
Why do you strive so? whither would you fly?
You cannot wrest yourself away from care
You may from council; you may shift your place
But not your person; and another climb
Makes you no other.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For passion's sake,
(Which I do serve, honour, and love in you)
If you will sigh, sigh here; if you would vary
A sigh to tears, or outcry, do it here.
No shade, no desert, darkness, nor the grave
Shall be more equal to your thoughts then I,
Only but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: What would you say?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That which shall raise your heart, or pull down mine,
Quiet your passion, or provoke mine own;
We must have both one balsam, or one wound,
For know (Loved fair) since the first providence
Made me your rescue, I have read you through,
And with a wondering pity, looked on you,
I have observed the method of your blood,
And waited on it even with sympathy
Of a like red, and paleness in mine own;
I knew which blush was angers, which was loves,
Which was the eye of sorrow, which of truth;
And could distinguish honour from disdain
In every change; and you are worth my study:
I saw your voluntary misery
Sustained in travel: a disguised maid
Wearied with seeking: and with finding lost,
Neglected, where you hoped most; or put by;
I saw it, and have laid it to my heart,
And though it were my sister, which was righted,
Yet being by your wrong, I put off nature,
Could not be glad, where I was bound to triumph,
My care for you, so drowned respect of her,
Nor did I only apprehend your bonds,
But studied your release: and for that day
Have I made up a ransom, brought you health
Preservative 'gainst chance, or injury
Please you apply it to the grief; myself.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Humh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay do not think me less than such a cure,
Antonio was not; and 'tis possible
Philippo may succeed: my blood and house
Are as deep rooted: and as fairly spread,
As Mark-antonio's, and in that, all seek,
Fortune hath given him no precedency:
As for our thanks to nature I may burn
Incense as much as he: I ever durst
Walk with Antonio oy the selfsame light
At any feast, or triumph, and never cared
Which side my lady or her woman took
In their survey; I durst have told my tale too
Though his discourse new ended.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: My repulse.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let not that torture you, which makes me happy
Nor think that conscience (Fair) which is no shame
'Twas no repulse, I was your dowry rather:
For then methought a thousand graces met
To make you lovely, and ten thousand storeys
Of constant virtue, which you then outreached,
In one example, did proclaim you rich
Nor do I think you wretched, or disgraced
After this suffering, and do therefore take
Advantage of your need; but rather know
You are the charge and business of those powers,
Who, like best tutors, do inflict hard tasks
Upon great natures, and of noblest hopes;
Read trivial lessons, and half lines to slugs;
They that live long and never feel mischance,
Spend more than half their age in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: 'Tis well you think so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You shall think so too,
You shall sweet Leocadia, and do so.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Good sir no more; you have too fair a shape
To play so foul a part in, as the tempter:
Say that I could make peace with fortune, who,
Who should absolve me of my vow yet; ha?
My contract made?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your contract?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Yes, my contract,
Am I not his? his wife?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet, nothing less.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I have no name then?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Truly then you have not;
How can you be his wife, who was before
Another's husband?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: O, though he dispense
With his faith given, I cannot with mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You do mistake (Clear soul) his precontract
Doth annul yours, and you have given no faith
That ties you in religion, or humanity,
You rather sin against that greater precept,
To covet what's another's; sweet, you do
Believe me, who dare not urge dishonest things,
Remove that scruple therefore, and but take
Your dangers now, into your judgements scale
And weigh them with your safeties: think but whither
Now you can go: what you can do to live?
How near you ha' barred all ports to your own succour,
Except this one that I here open: love
Should you be left alone, you were a prey
To the wild lust of any, who would look
Upon this shape like a temptation
And think you want the man you personate
Would not regard this shift, which love put on
As virtue forced but covet it like vice;
So should you live the slander of each sex,
And be the child of error, and of shame,
And which is worse, even Mark-antony
Would be called just, to turn a wanderer off,
And fame report you worthy his contempt;
Where if you make new choice, and settle here
There is no further tumult in this flood.
Each currant keeps his course, and all suspicions
Shall return honours: came you forth a maid?
Go home a wife? alone? and in disguise?
Go home a waited Leocadia:
Go home, and by the virtue of that charm
Transform all mischiefs, as you are transformed;
Turn your offended father's wrath to wonder,
And all his loud grief to a silent welcome:
Unfold the riddles you have made, what say you?
sp.stage: Enter Sanchio carried, Alphonso, and servants.
sp.l: Now is the time; delay is but despair,
If you be changed, let a kiss tell me so.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: I am: but how, I rather feel than know.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Come sir; you are welcome now to Barcelona,
Take off my hood.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who be these? stay, let's view 'em?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: 'Twas a long journey: are you not weary sir?

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Weary? I could have rid it in mine armour.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What ail you deer?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: It is my father.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your father: which?

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: He that is carried: o
Let us make hence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For love's sake: good my heart.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: Into some house before he see me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dear,
Be not thus frighted.

sp.speaker: Leoc.
sp.l: O his wrath is tempest.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet, take your spirit to you, and stay be't he,
He cannot know you in this habit, and me
I'm sure he less knows, for he never saw me.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Ha? who is that? my son Philippo?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: Why, what make you here? Is this Salamanca?
And that your study? ha? nay stay him too,
We'll see him by his leave.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You must not strive sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: No, no, come near.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: My daughter: Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: How sir: your daughter?

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Yes sir, and as sure
As that's your son: come hither: what now? run
Out of your sex? breeched? was't not enough
At once to leave thy father, and thine honour,
Unless th' hadst quit thyself too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir what fault
She can be urged off, I must take on me
The guilt, and punishment.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: You must sir: how
If you shall not, though you must? I deal not
With boys sir; ay, you have a father here
Shall do me right.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Thou art not mad Philippo?
Art thou Mark-antony? Son to Leonardo?
Our business is to them.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: No, no, no, no,
I'll ha' the business now: with you, none else,
Pray you let's speak, in private: (Carry me to him)
Your son's the ravisher sir, and here I find him:
I hope you'll give me cause to think you noble,
And do me right, with your sword sir, as becomes
One gentleman of honour to another;
All this is fair sir: here's the sea fast by,
Upon the sands, we will determine
'Tis that I call you too; let's make no days on't,
I'll lead your way; to the seaside rascals.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir
I would beseech your stay; he may not follow you.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No, turn I'll kill him here then: slaves, rogues, blocks
Why do you not bear me to him? ha' you been
Acquainted with my motions, logs, so long
And yet not know to time 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Were you sir
Not impotent.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Hold you your peace boy.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Impotent
'Death I'll cut his throat first, and then his fathers.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: You must provide you then a sharper razor
Then is your tongue, for I not fear your sword.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: 'Heart bear me to either of'em .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray sir your patience.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My curse light on thee if thou stay him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Why, what's the matter, gentlemen, what tumult
Is this you raise i'th street? before my door?
Know you what 'tis to draw a weapon here.

sp.speaker: Sanc.
sp.l: Yes, and to use it (Bear me up to him, rogues)
Thus, at a traitor's heart.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Truer then thine.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Strike, strike; some of the people disarm 'em,
Kill 'em if they resist.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay generous sir
Let not your courtesy turn fury now.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Lay hold upon 'em, take away their weapons,
I will be worth an answer, ere we part.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis the governor sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I yield myself.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: My sword? what thinkst thou of me? pray thee tell me.

sp.speaker: 1 attend
sp.l: As of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: 1 attend
sp.l: Of worth,
And quality.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: And I should quit my sword
There were small worth or quality in that friend;
Pray thee learn thou more worth and quality
Then to demand it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Force it I say.

sp.speaker: 1 attendant
sp.l: The governor
You hear, commands.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: The governor shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How, Leocadia gone again? Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: He shall friend
I'th point of honour; by his leave, so tell him,
His person and authority I acknowledge,
And do submit me to it; but my sword,
He shall excuse me, were he fifteen governors;
That and I dwell together, and must yet
Till my hands part, assure him.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I say force it.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Stay, hear me. Hast thou ever read Curanza?
Understandest thou honour, noble governor?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: For that we'll have more fit dispute.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Your name sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You shall know that too: but on colder terms,
Your blood and brain are now too hot to take it.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Force my sword from me? this is an affront.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Bring 'em away.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: You'll do me reparation. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have for ever lost her, and am lost,
And worthily: my tameness hath undone me;
She's gone hence, ashamed of me: yet I seek her.
Will she be ever found to me again,
Whom she saw stand so poorly, and dare nothing
In her defence, here, when I should have drawn
This sword out like a meteor, and have shot it
In both our parents eyes, and left 'em blind
Unto their impotent angers? O I am worthy
On whom this loss and scorn should light to death
Without the pity that should wish me better,
Either alive, or in my epitaph.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Well son, your father is too near himself
And hath too much of nature to put off
Any affection that belongs to you.
I could have only wished you had acquainted
Her father, whom it equally concerns,
Though y'had presumed on me: it might have opened
An easier gate, and path to both our joys:
For though I am none of those flinty fathers
That when their children do but natural things,
Turn rock and offence straight: yet Marc-antonio,
All are not of my quarry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis my fear sir;
And if hereafter I should ere abuse
So great a piety, it were my malice.

sp.speaker: Attendant
sp.l: We must entreat you gentlemen to take
Another room, the governor is coming
Here, on some business.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We will give him way.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will have right sir on you; that believe,
If there be any marshals court in Spain.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: For that sir we shall talk.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: — do not slight me,
Though I am without a sword.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Keep to your chair sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: — Let me fall, and hurl my chair! (Slaves) at him.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: You are the more tempered man sir: let me entreat
Of you the manner how this brawl fell out.

sp.speaker: Alph
sp.l: Fell out? I know not how: nor do I care much:
But here we came sir to this town together,
Both in one business and one wrong, engaged
To seek one Leonardo an old Genoese,
I ha' said enough there; would you more? false father
Of a false son, called Marc-antonio,
Who had stole both our daughters; and which father
Conspiring with his son in treachery,
It seemed, to fly our satisfaction,
Was, as we heard, come private to this town
Here to take ship for Italy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You heard
More than was true then: by the fear, or falsehood,
And though I thought not to reveal myself
(Pardon my manners in't to you) for some
Important reasons; yet being thus charactered
And challenged, know I dare appear, and do
To who dares threaten.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I say he is not worthy
The name of man, or any honest preface,
That dares report or credit such a slander.
Do you sir say it?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Sir, I do say it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Hold,
Is this your father signior Marc-antonio?
You have ill requited me thus to conceal him
From him would honour him, and do him service.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: 'Twas not his fault sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Where's my lord.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Know you these gentlemen? they are all the fathers
Unto our friends.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: So it appears my dove.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Sir I say nothing: I do want a sword,
And till I have a sword I will say nothing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Good sir command these gentlemen their arms;
Entreat 'em as your friends, not as your prisoners.
Where be their swords?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Restore each man his weapon.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: It seems thou hast not read Curanza, fellow
I must have reparation of honour,
As well as this; I find that wounded.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir,
I did not know your quality, if I had
'Tis like I should have done you more respects.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: It is sufficient, by Caranza's rule.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I know it is sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Have you read Caranza lady?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: If you mean him that writ upon the duel,
He was my kinsman.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Lady, than you know
By the right noble writings of your kinsman,
My honour is as dear to me, as the Kings.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Tis very true sir.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Therefore I must crave
Leave to go on now with my first dependence.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What ha' you more?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: None here good signior.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I will, refer me to Claranza still.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay love, I prithee let me manage this.
With whom is't sir?

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: With that false man Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why he has th'advantage sir in legs.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: But I
In truth, and hand and heart, and a good sword.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But how if he will not stand you sir.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: For that,
Make it no question lady, I will stick
My feet in earth down by him, where he dare.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: O would thou wouldst.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Let me kiss him.
I fear thou wilt not yet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why gentlemen,
If you'll proceed according to Curanza,
Methinks an easier way, were too good chairs,
So you would be content sir to be bound,
'Cause he is lame, I'll fit you with like weapons,
Pistols and poniards, and e'en end it. If
The difference between you be so mortal.
It cannot be ta'en up.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Ta'e up? take off
This head first.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Come bind me in a chair.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yes, do.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: What mean you, dove.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Let me alone,
And set 'em at their distance: when you ha' done
Lend me two poniards; I'll have pistols ready
Quickly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She is not here Marc-antonio.
Saw you not Leocadia?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not I brother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Brother let's speak with you; you were false unto her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was, but have asked pardon: why do you urge it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You were not worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: May be I was not;
But 'tis not well, you tell me so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My sister
Is not so fair.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It skills not.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor so virtuous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, she must be as virtuous.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would fain —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What brother?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Strike you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall not bear strokes
Though I do these strange words.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will you not kill me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For what good brother?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why, for speaking well
Of Leocadia.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor ill
Of Theodosia?

div.stage: Enter Eugenia, Leocadia, Theodosia, and one with two pistols.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fare you well then.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay you shall have as noble seconds too
As ever duelists had; give 'em their weapons:
Now saint Jago.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: Are they charged?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Charged sir,
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Would they were well discharged.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I like a sword much better I confess.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Nay wherefore stay you? shall I mend your mark?
Strike one another, through these?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My love.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: My Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Sanch.
sp.l: I ha' not the heart.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Why here is a dependence ended.
Unbind that gentleman; come take here to you
Your sons and daughters, and be friends. A feast
Waits you within, is better than your fray:
Lovers, take you your own, and all forbear
Under my roof, either to blush or fear
My love, what say you; could Cuzanza himself
Carry a business better?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: It is well:
All are content I hope, and we well eased,
If they for whom we have done all this be pleased.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: To this place gentlemen, full many a day
We have bid ye welcome; and to many a play:
And those whose angry souls were not diseased
With law, or lending money, we have pleased;
And make no doubt to do again. This night
No mighty matter, nor no light,
We must entreat you look for: a good tale
Told in two hours, we will not fail
If we be perfect to rehearse ye: new
I am sure it is, and handsome; but how true
Let them dispute that writ it, ten to one
We please the women; and I would know that man
Follows not their example. If ye mean
To know the play well, travel with the scene.
For it lies upon the road; if we chance tire,
As ye are good men leave us not i'th mire,
Another bait may mend us: if you grow
A little galled or weary; cry but hoa,
And we'll stay for ye. When our journey ends
Every man's pot I hope, and all part friends.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
